abstract: Haplotype-based methods offer a powerful approach to disease gene mapping, based on the association between causal mutations and the ancestral haplotypes on which they arose. As part of The SNP Consortium Allele Frequency Projects, we characterized haplotype patterns across 51 autosomal regions (spanning 13 megabases of the human genome) in samples from Africa, Europe, and Asia. We show that the human genome can be parsed objectively into haplotype blocks: sizable regions over which there is little evidence for historical recombination and within which only a few common haplotypes are observed. The boundaries of blocks and specific haplotypes they contain are highly correlated across populations. We demonstrate that such haplotype frameworks provide substantial statistical power in association studies of common genetic variation across each region. Our results provide a foundation for the construction of a haplotype map of the human genome, facilitating comprehensive genetic association studies of human disease.

GroEL, a heat-shock protein that acts as a molecular chaperone1, is overproduced in endosymbiotic but not in free-living bacteria2,3,4, presumably to assist in the folding of conformationally damaged proteins. Here we show that the overproduction of GroEL in Escherichia coli masks the effects of harmful mutations that have accumulated during a simulated process of vertical transmission. This molecular mechanism, which may be an adaptation to the bacterium's intracellular lifestyle, is able to rescue lineages from a progressive fitness decline resulting from the fixation of deleterious mutations under strong genetic drift5,6.

Although deoxythymidylate cannot be provided directly by ribonucleotide reductase, the gene encoding thymidylate synthase ThyA is absent from the genomes of a large number of nonsymbiotic microbes. We show that ThyX (Thy1) proteins of previously unknown function form a large and distinct class of thymidylate synthases. ThyX has a wide but sporadic phylogenetic distribution, almost exclusively limited to microbial genomes lacking thyA. ThyX and ThyA use different reductive mechanisms, because ThyX activity is dependent on reduced flavin nucleotides. Our findings reveal complexity in the evolution of thymidine in present-day DNA. Because ThyX proteins are found in many pathogenic microbes, they present a previously uncharacterized target for antimicrobial compounds.

A thin outer ice shell on Jupiter's large moon Europa would imply easy exchange between the surface and any organic or biotic material in its putative subsurface ocean. The thickness of the outer ice shell is poorly constrained, however, with model-dependent estimates ranging from a few kilometres to ten or more kilometres. Here I present measurements of depths of impact craters on Europa, Ganymede and Callisto that reveal two anomalous transitions in crater shape with diameter. The first transition is probably related to temperature-dependent ductility of the crust at shallow depths (7 8 km on Europa). The second transition is attributed to the influence of subsurface oceans on all three satellites, which constrains Europa's icy shell to be at least 19 km thick. The icy lithospheres of Ganymede and Callisto are equally ice-rich, but Europa's icy shell has a thermal structure about 0.25 0.5 times the thicknesses of Ganymede's or Callisto's shells, depending on epoch. The appearances of the craters on Europa are inconsistent with thin-ice-shell models and indicate that exchange of oceanic and surface material could be difficult.

Angiogenesis is an essential prerequisite for tumor growth, invasion, and metastasis. In ovarian carcinoma cells, endothelin-1 (ET-1) stimulates the secretion of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), a major mediator of tumor angiogenesis. In OVCA 433 and HEY ovarian carcinoma cell lines, ET-1 treatment increases VEGF mRNA expression and induces VEGF protein levels in a time- and dose-dependent fashion, and do so to a greater extent under hypoxic conditions. ET-1 also increases hypoxia-inducible factor-1α (HIF-1α) accumulation and activates the HIF-1 transcription complex under both normoxic and hypoxic conditions, suggesting a role for HIF-1 in the induction of VEGF expression. These effects are inhibited by the selective ETA receptor (ETAR) antagonist, BQ123. The ET-1-induced increase in HIF-1α protein levels is due to the enhanced HIF-1α stabilization. These results implicate HIF-1α in the induction of VEGF expression in ET-1-stimulated ovarian carcinoma cells, and provide a mechanism whereby ET-1 acting selectively through ETAR can interact with the HIF-1α-dependent machinery of angiogenesis. Our results suggest that new therapeutic strategies using specific ETAR antagonists could provide an additional approach to the treatment of ovarian carcinoma by inhibiting neovascularization as well as tumor cell growth. High levels of ET-1 were detected in the majority of ascitic fluids of these patients and significantly correlated with VEGF ascitic concentrations (12Salani D., Di Castro V. Nicotra M.R. Rosanò L. Vouret-Craviari V. Pouysségur J. Oncogene. 2001; 20: 1556-1562Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar). Thus, ET-1 modulates different stages of neovascularization including proliferation, migration, invasion, protease production, and morphogenesis of human umbilical vein endothelial cells and stimulates neovascularization in vivo (11Salani D. Hypertension. 1995; 25: 913-917Crossref PubMed Scopus (266) Google Scholar, 18Pedram A. Razandi M., Hu, R.M. Levin E.R. J. Biol. In the ovarian carcinoma cell line, OVCA 433, we demonstrated that ET-1 stimulated VEGF production through ETAR by an extent comparable with hypoxia, indicating that ET-1 could modulate tumor angiogenesis through direct angiogenic effects on endothelial cells and through the VEGF stimulation (12Salani D., Di Castro V. Nicotra M.R. Rosanò L. Tecce R. Venuti A. Natali P.G. Bagnato A. Am. J. Pathol. 2000; 157: 1537-1547Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (179) Google Scholar). Transcriptional up-regulation of the hypoxia-inducible factor-1 (HIF-1) has been shown to play a major role in VEGF gene induction (19Forsythe J.A. Jiang B.H. Iyer N.V. Agani F. Leung S.W. Koos R.D. Semenza G.L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 4604-4613Crossref PubMed Scopus (3215) Google Scholar). Trends Cell Biol. 2001; 11: S32-S36Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (130) Google Scholar). Biol. 2000; 35: 71-103Crossref PubMed Scopus (569) Google Scholar, 2Kourembahas S. Maraden P.A. Mequillanm L.P. Faller D.V. J. Clin. Chem. 2001; 276: 12645-12653Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (291) Google Scholar, 19Forsythe J.A. Jiang B.H. Iyer N.V. Agani F. Leung S.W. Koos R.D. Semenza G.L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 4604-4613Crossref PubMed Scopus (3215) Google Scholar). HIF-1 is up-regulated in a broad range of malignancies, where it correlates with tumor grade and vascularity (21Maxwell P.H. Pugh C.W. Ratcliffe P.J. Curr. Opin. Genet. & Dev. 2001; 11: 293-299Crossref PubMed Scopus (341) Google Scholar). Although the HIF-1β protein is readily found in all cells, HIF-1α, which is virtually undetectable under normal oxygen conditions, is strongly and rapidly induced by hypoxia. Oxygen-dependent proline hydroxylation regulates the binding of von Hippel-Lindau suppressor protein, the recognition component of a ubiquitin-protein ligase that targets HIF-1α for ubiquitination and proteosomal degradation (22Ivan M. Kaelin W.G., Jr. Curr. Opin. Genet. & Dev. 2001; 11: 27-34Crossref PubMed Scopus (187) Google Scholar, 23Darren E.R. Edurne B. Pouysségur J. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 26765-26771Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 24Semenza G.L. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 2001; 13: 167-171Crossref PubMed Scopus (897) Google Scholar). Although hypoxia has been shown to be the major inducer of HIF-1α in all cells tested, other stimuli, such as growth factors, hormones, nitric oxide, transition metals, and iron chelators, are able to induce VEGF expression in an HIF-1-dependent manner in normoxic cells (25Goldberg M.A. Schneider T.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 4355-4359Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 26Jiang B.H. Zheng J.Z. Laung S.W. Roe R. Semenza G.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 19253-19260Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (549) Google Scholar, 27Zelzer E. Levy Y. Kahana C. Shilo B.Z. Rubinstein M. Cohen B. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 5085-5094Crossref PubMed Scopus (495) Google Scholar, 28Kimura H. Weisz A. Kurashima Y. Hashimoto K. Ogura T. D'Acquisto F. Addeo R. Makuuchi M. Esumi H. Blood. 2000; 95: 189-197Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 29Laughner E. Taghavi P. Chiles K. Mahon P.C. Semenza G.L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2001; 21: 3995-4004Crossref PubMed Scopus (1126) Google Scholar). We hypothesized that ET-1 promotes VEGF production through HIF-1α and that this mechanism may be responsible for the increasing angiogenesis resulting in ovarian tumor growth. Therefore, we used HEY and OVCA 433 ovarian carcinoma cell lines as a model to investigate the stimulation of VEGF expression by ET-1 and the mechanisms involved in ET-1 induction of VEGF. Because ET-1 stimulates ovarian tumor cell proliferation and survival selectively through ETAR, which is the receptor subtype predominantly expressed in these tumor cells, we also explored which receptor is involved in the ET-1-induced VEGF expression. Here we report that ET-1 induces VEGF expression in ovarian cancer cells grown under normal oxygen conditions. ET-1-increased VEGF expression was mediated by ETAR and was associated with the induction of HIF-1α protein, suggesting a role for HIF-1 in this effect. Furthermore, we found that ET-1 enhanced HIF-1α stability leading to HIF-1α protein accumulation, and these effects were amplified under hypoxic conditions. Our results clearly demonstrated that ET-1 mimics cellular hypoxia inducing HIF-1α protein that can form the HIF-1 transcription complex inducing higher levels of HIF-1 DNA binding activity in ovarian carcinoma cells. These findings suggest that this ETAR-activated pathway should play a major role in vascular VEGF production and neovascularization in ovarian carcinoma. OVCA 433 and HEY human ovarian carcinoma cell lines were the generous gifts from Prof. Giovanni Scambia (Catholic University School of Medicine, Rome, Italy) and were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium containing 10% fetal calf serum, 2 mml-glutamine, and 1% penicillin/streptomycin. Cells were routinely cultured in 5% CO2, 95% air (normoxic conditions) at 37 °C. To expose cells to hypoxia, cells were placed into an air-tight chamber (Modular Incubator Chamber, Billups-Rothenberg, CA) with inflow and outflow valves and were infused with a mixture of 5% CO2, 95% N2 for 20 min. In all experiments cells were grown to 70–80% confluence on 100-mm glass dishes. Cells were then serum-deprived by incubation for 24 h in serum-free medium and exposed to normoxia or hypoxia in the presence or in the absence of ET-1 or BQ123, a specific ETAR antagonist (Peninsula Laboratories, Belmont, CA). All culture reagents were from Invitrogen. When the effects of ETAR antagonist were studied, BQ123 was added 15 min before the agonist. Pretreatment with cycloheximide (100 μm, Sigma) was performed 2 h prior to the addition of ET-1 for de novo protein synthesis of VEGF. For the HIF-1α stability study, cycloheximide was added after 24 h of ET-1 or hypoxic treatment, and the cells were further incubated under normoxia for varying times. Total RNA from HEY and OVCA 433 cells was extracted using the TRIzol (Invitrogen) method according to the manufacturer's instructions. RT-PCR was performed on 1 μg of total RNA using a Superscript One-step RT-PCR System (Invitrogen) according to the manufacturer's instructions. The primer sets were as follows: VEGF, 5′-GGCTCTAGATCGGGCCTCCGAAACCAT-3′ and 5′- GGCTCTAGAGCGCAGAGTCTCCTCTTC-3′; GAPDH, 5′-TGAAGGTCGGTGTCAACGGA-3′and 5′-GATGGCATGGACTGTGGTCAT-3′. Thirty five cycles of amplification with a PerkinElmer Life Sciences 9700 thermocycler were performed under the following conditions: melting at 95 °C for 30 s; annealing at 60 °C for 45 s; extension at 72 °C for 30s for VEGF amplification, and for GAPDH amplification a 55 °C annealing temperature was used. The PCR products were analyzed by electrophoresis on a 2% agarose gel containing ethidium bromide and visualized and photographed under UV light. In all experiments, two control reactions, one containing no mRNA and another containing mRNA but no reverse transcriptase, were included. OVCA 433 and HEY cells were seeded at 1 × 106 cells/dish in complete medium and serum-starved for 24 h. Cells were cultured under normoxic and hypoxic conditions. After varying times conditioned media were collected, centrifuged, and frozen for subsequent use. The VEGF protein levels in the media were determined in duplicate by ELISA using the reagents and the protocol supplied with the Quantikine Human VEGF immunoassay kit (R & D Systems, Minneapolis, MN). Cells were washed with ice-cold phosphate-buffered saline and lysed by scraping with a rubber policeman in lysis buffer (50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.4, 250 mmNaCl, 50 mm sodium fluoride, 5 mm EDTA, 0.15% Triton X-100, 1 mm orthovanadate, 0.06 units of aprotinin, 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, and 10 μg/ml leupeptin). Protein concentrations were determined by the BCA Protein assay (Pierce). Protein cell extracts were subjected to SDS-polyacrylamide gel (7.5%) and transferred to nitrocellulose. The filters were blocked with 5% bovine serum albumin in TBST (10 mm Tris, pH 8.0, 150 mm NaCl, 0.05% Tween) and incubated with VEGF polyclonal (Sigma) or HIF-1α monoclonal antibody (Transduction Laboratories, Lexington, KY) for 3 h. After washing with TBST, blots were incubated with peroxidase-conjugated anti-goat IgG or anti-mouse IgG for VEGF or HIF-1α, respectively, washed again, and subjected to the ECL (Amersham Biosciences) procedure. The presence of VEGF was also assayed in HEY cell-conditioned medium and analyzed by Western blotting. Total RNA from HEY cells was extracted using the TRIzol (Invitrogen) method according to the manufacturer's instructions, separated by electrophoresis on 2% denaturing formaldehyde-agarose gel, and transferred to a nylon membrane. The membranes were UV cross-linked and hybridized in the QuickHyb hybridization solution (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA) according to the manufacturer's instructions. The cDNA probe used for analysis of the VEGF and GAPDH mRNA was prepared using RT-PCR products. Probes were labeled with [α-32P]dCTP using a random primer Oligolabeling kit (Amersham Biosciences) according to the manufacturer's instructions. Densitometric scanning was performed with a Mustek MFS-6000 CX apparatus, and the data were analyzed with Phoretix 1D software and normalized to those of GAPDH. HEY cells were grown as before and lysed in buffer A (50 mm HCl, 0.5% Nonidet P-40, 25 mm Hepes, 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 10 μg/ml leupeptin, 20 μg/ml aprotinin, 100 μm dithiothreitol). The lysates were pelleted and resuspended in buffer B (500 mm HCl, 25 mm Hepes, 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 10 μg/ml leupeptin, 20 μg/ml aprotinin, 100 μmdithiothreitol, 10% glycerol). Nuclear debris was removed by centrifugation, and aliquots of the supernatant were stored at −80 °C. Oligonucleotide (130 ng) corresponding to the HRE sequence of the VEGF gene (5′-TCGACCACAGTGCATACGTGGGCTCCAACAGGTCCTCTTC-3′) was labeled with [α-32P]dCTP (3000 Ci/mmol) (30Aragonès J. Jones D.R. Martin S. San Juan M.A. Alfranca A. Vidal F. Vara A. Merida I. Landazuri M.O. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 10548-10555Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar). Nuclear extracts (5 μg of protein) were preincubated (15 min at room temperature) together with poly(dI-dC) (Sigma) in 20 μl of buffer consisting of Tris-HCl (pH 7.5, 10 mm), 100 mmKCl, 1 mm MgCl2, 1 mm EDTA, 5 mm dithiothreitol. The labeled probe (3 × 104 cpm) was then added and incubation continued for an additional 15 min. For competition assay, the labeled probe was mixed with a 100-fold molar excess of unlabeled oligonucleotide and then added to the nuclear extract. For supershift assays HIF-1α antibody (Transduction Laboratories) was added to the nuclear extract at a final dilution of 1:3 immediately after addition of the probe, and the mixture was kept on ice for 20 min. Reaction mixtures were then loaded onto 5% non-denaturing polyacrylamide gels. Electrophoresis was performed in 0.5× TBE (40 mm Tris-HCl, 45 mmboric acid, and 2.5 mm EDTA). Gels were vacuum-dried and autoradiographed overnight at −80 °C. All statistical analyses were assessed using a two-tailed Student's t test and performed by the Inplot software system (GraphPad Software Inc., San Diego, CA). We first performed RT-PCR analysis to determine whether ET-1 affects the levels of VEGF mRNA in HEY and OVCA 433 cells, which produce elevated amount of ET-1 and express high affinity ETA receptors (31Bagnato A. Tecce R. Moretti C., Di Castro V. Spergel D. Catt K.J. Clin. Cancer Res. 1995; 1: 1059-1066PubMed Google Scholar, 32Salani, D., Rosanò, L., Di Castro, V., Spinella, F., Venuti, A., Padley, R. J., Nicotra, M. R., Natali, P. G., and Bagnato, A. (2002) Clin. Sci. (Lond.)102,Google Scholar). Ovarian carcinoma cells were incubated with different concentrations of ET-1 ranging from 0.01 to 100 nm. ET-1 increased the three VEGF transcript levels corresponding to VEGF121, VEGF165, and VEGF189 in a concentration-dependent manner (Fig. 1). VEGF transcript levels were markedly enhanced by 1 nm ET-1, with a further increase induced by 10 nm reaching maximal stimulation by 100 nm. We next assessed whether induction of VEGF mRNA levels by ET-1 resulted in a parallel increase of VEGF protein in a time- and concentration-dependent manner. Conditioned medium from OVCA 433 and HEY cells incubated in the presence of various concentrations of ET-1 and for different times was assayed for secreted VEGF by ELISA analysis. After ET-1 stimulation, secreted VEGF levels increased progressively with detectable production as early as 1 h and maximum stimulation (2.5-fold above control levels) at 24 h (p ≤ 0.005, Fig.2 A). VEGF production increased progressively when HEY and OVCA 433 cells were treated with different concentrations of ET-1, reaching maximal stimulation at a concentration of 100 nm (p ≤ 0.005, Fig. 2 B). After 24 h of incubation with 100 nm ET-1, VEGF production was stimulated to an extent comparable with that induced by hypoxia (Fig. 2 B), a recognized potent stimulus of VEGF. We next investigated whether ET-1 cooperated with hypoxia, increasing the induction of VEGF production. After 12 and 24 h of hypoxic stimulus in HEY cells, ET-1-induced VEGF production increased progressively up to 1.5- and 2.0-fold above control levels, respectively (Fig. 2 C). These results indicated that ET-1 induced VEGF production in a manner comparable with hypoxia and that under hypoxic conditions ET-1 cooperated to hypoxia amplifying the VEGF production. To analyze whether ET-1-induced expression of VEGF was dependent onde novo protein synthesis, we determined the effect of the protein synthesis inhibitor cycloheximide (CHX) alone or in combination with ET-1. As shown in Fig. 2 D, induction of VEGF protein upon ET-1 treatment in OVCA 433 cells was strongly inhibited by CHX, suggesting that induction of VEGF expression by ET-1 was dependent on ongoing protein synthesis. To characterize the ET-1 receptor subtype involved in the up-regulation of VEGF mRNA, we performed Northern blotting. Densitometric analysis of Northern blot autoradiographic bands and comparison with the intensity of the bands of the GAPDH expression indicated that VEGF expression after 6 h of stimulation with ET-1 (100 nm), under normoxic conditions, was increased up to 2.6-fold above control levels to an extent comparable with that induced by hypoxia. In addition, under hypoxic conditions ET-1 increased VEGF mRNA expression 1.7-fold above the control levels (Fig.3 A). Pretreatment of cells with the ETAR antagonist BQ123 (1 μm) completely blocked the ET-1-stimulated VEGF mRNA expression under normoxic and hypoxic conditions (Fig. 3 A). To define the receptor-mediated action of ET-1 on VEGF protein production, we also analyzed conditioned media collected from HEY cells cultured for 24 h with ET-1 (100 nm) by Western blotting and by ELISA (Fig. 3, B and C). As evaluated by ELISA, ET-1-induced VEGF secretion increased up to 1.7- and 1.9-fold above control levels under normoxic and hypoxic conditions, respectively. After 24 h of incubation, the VEGF stimulation by ET-1 was completely blocked by BQ123 under both conditions (Fig. 3, B and C). These results indicated that ET-1-induced VEGF expression and secretion were mediated by the ETAR. To investigate whether ET-1-induced VEGF expression may be mediated by HIF-1α, we analyzed the HIF-1α protein levels upon ET-1 treatment in HEY cells cultured under normoxic or hypoxic conditions by Western blotting. The HIF-1α protein expression under normal oxygen conditions was undetectable, while exposure of HEY cells to hypoxia rapidly increased HIF-1α protein levels. At the end of 24 h stimulation with ET-1 (100 nm) in normoxic HEY cells, the HIF-1α protein expression was strongly induced to a level that was more elevated than the hypoxic treatment (Fig. 4 A). When HEY cells were stimulated with 100 nm ET-1 under hypoxic conditions, the level of HIF-1α induction was increased to an even greater extent than that induced by hypoxia. We then evaluated whether HIF-1α accumulation induced by ET-1 was associated with the VEGF protein expression. Both in normoxic or hypoxic HEY cells, ET-1-induced accumulation of HIF-1α protein paralleled the ET-1-induced VEGF production (Fig. 4 B). The undetectable expression of HIF-1α in non-stimulated HEY cells suggested that the HIF-1α protein was unstable under normoxic conditions in this cell line. To assess whether ET-1 regulated the expression of HIF-1α protein by inhibiting its degradation, we monitored the levels of ET-1-induced HIF-1α protein after blocking protein synthesis by cycloheximide. To this end, we investigated the decay of hypoxia-stabilized HIF-1α after transfer of cells from hypoxia to normoxia. A rapid decay of HIF-1α protein was observed within 15 min and was completely undetectable by the end of 60 min under normoxia (Fig. 5 A). In contrast, ET-1-induced HIF-1α protein levels under normoxia remained constant for 60 min after cycloheximide addition and decreased relatively slowly to ∼40% within 120 min thereafter (Fig.5 B). Moreover, the decay of hypoxia-stabilized HIF-1α after transfer of cells from hypoxia to normoxia in the presence of ET-1 was found to occur at a greater extent than hypoxia alone and with kinetics in which the levels of HIF-1α protein were still detectable and clearly above basal levels after 3 h of cycloheximide exposure. These results clearly indicated that ET-1 induced HIF-1α protein in normoxic and hypoxic HEY cells by slowing down its degradation. The finding that increased levels of VEGF expression were associated with the stabilization of HIF-1α protein in ET-1-treated HEY cells may be indicative of a role for HIF-1α in the induction of VEGF expression by ET-1. To be active, HIF-1α must form the HIF-1 transcription complex with HIF-1β and bind to the specific HRE DNA sequence (20Brahimi C. Berra E. Pouysségur J. Trends Cell Biol. 2001; 11: S32-S36Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (130) Google Scholar). Therefore, we evaluated HIF-1 DNA binding activity with electrophoretic mobility shift assay experiments. When a 40-bp 32P-labeled oligonucleotide probe containing the HIF-1-binding site was incubated with nuclear extracts from ET-1-treated HEY cells, under normoxic and hypoxic conditions, a number of protein-DNA complexes were increased (Fig.6). The identity of HIF-1 in these complexes was confirmed by competition experiments and the use of a specific antibody. A 100-fold excess of unlabeled oligonucleotide competed with the probe for the binding of HIF-1α. A specific monoclonal antibody against HIF-1α was able to supershift the hypoxia-inducible complexes without affecting constitutive DNA-protein complexes. This induction was mediated through ETAR binding, as demonstrated by the inhibitory effect on the induction of HIF-1 DNA complex by BQ123 under both hypoxic and normoxic conditions. These results indicated that ET-1 mimics hypoxia to induce HIF-1α protein that can form the HIF-1 complex with HIF-1β and bind the HRE sequence and that this mechanism is mediated through ETAR. In addition to the classical hypoxia-mediated induction of VEGF, a number of angiogenic stimuli including several tyrosine kinase receptors and GPCR agonists have also been shown to induce VEGF expression through HIF-1α (25Goldberg M.A. Schneider T.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 4355-4359Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 27Zelzer E. Levy Y. Kahana C. Shilo B.Z. Rubinstein M. Cohen B. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 5085-5094Crossref PubMed Scopus (495) Google Scholar, 33Feldser D. Agani F. Iyer N.V. Pak B. Ferreira G. Semenza G.L. Cancer Res. 1999; 59: 3915-3918PubMed Google Scholar, 34Sodhi A. Montaner S. Patel V. Zohar M. Bais C. Mesri E.A. Gutkind S. Cancer Res. 2000; 60: 4873-4880PubMed Google Scholar). Among the latter we have reported (11Salani D. Taraboletti G. Rosanò L., Di Castro V. Borsotti P. Giavazzi R. Bagnato A. Am. J. Pathol. 2000; 157: 1703-1711Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (309) Google Scholar, 12Salani D., Di Castro V. Nicotra M.R. Rosanò L. Tecce R. Venuti A. Natali P.G. Bagnato A. Am. J. Pathol. 2000; 157: 1537-1547Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (179) Google Scholar) that ET-1 induces an angiogenic phenotype on endothelial cells and neovascularization in ovarian carcinoma. In this study we demonstrated that ET-1 enhanced VEGF mRNA and protein levels in ovarian carcinoma cell lines via ETAR. This modulation is associated in HEY cells with the accumulation of HIF-1α protein indicating a role for HIF-1 in the induction of VEGF expression. ET-1 induced HIF-1α stability and potentiated the hypoxia-mediated induction of HIF-1α and VEGF expression. Furthermore, ET-1 shares with hypoxia the ability to induce a complex that binds HRE as demonstrated by electrophoretic mobility shift assay. Steady-state levels of HIF-1α protein were regulated at the level of synthesis and stability. Many activators of HIF-1α, including hypoxia, have been shown to induce HIF-1α protein expression by inhibiting ubiquitination and degradation (24Semenza G.L. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 2001; 13: 167-171Crossref PubMed Scopus (897) Google Scholar). To investigate whether ET-1 induced HIF-1α protein accumulation through a similar mechanism in HEY cells, we examined the kinetics of the decay of ET-1-induced HIF-1α protein in the absence of protein synthesis. As a reference for the stability of HIF-1α under normoxia in non-treated HEY cells, we investigated the decay of hypoxia-stabilized HIF-1α protein upon reoxygenation in the same manner. Analysis of HIF-1α protein stability in cycloheximide-treated cells showed that the degradation of HIF-1α was decreased in ET-1-treated cells compared with control under both hypoxic and normoxic conditions, supporting the notion that the induction of HIF-1α protein level by ET-1 was due to enhanced HIF-1α stability. Our results confirmed findings reporting that HIF-1α protein was unstable in normoxic OVCAR-3 and HI34 ovarian carcinoma cell lines and demonstrated the induction of VEGF expression and HIF-1α protein by the oxidative stressor arsenite (35Duyndam M.C.A. Hulscher T.M. Fontijn D. Pinedo H.M. Boven E. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 48066-48076Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar). In this study we have shown that after stimulation with ET-1 increased HIF-1α protein levels accumulated in the cells, and the HIF-1 transcription complex was formed and could bind to the HRE-binding site. Therefore, ET-1-induced HIF-1 accumulation in ovarian carcinoma cell lines activated all the signals necessary for a full HIF-1 response. These findings indicate that under normoxic conditions ET-1 was able to activate the hypoxia response pathway, which is the strongest physiological regulator of VEGF expression implying a direct involvement of ET-1 in the elicitation of the angiogenic phenotype. The HIF-1α-mediated transcription of VEGF by ET-1 under normoxic conditions pointed to a general mechanism through which oncogenes and growth factors may up-regulate VEGF and could synergize with hypoxia during tumor growth. In human cancers, HIF-1α was overexpressed as a result of intratumoral hypoxia and genetic alterations affecting key oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes. HIF-1α overexpression in biopsies of brain, breast, cervical, esophageal, oropharyngeal, and ovarian cancer was correlated with treatment failure and mortality (36Semenza G.L. Mol. Med. 2002; 8: S62-S67Scopus (931) Google Scholar). Overexpression of HIF-1α protein, as demonstrated by immunohistochemistry, was observed in 68.6% of epithelial ovarian cancer specimens (37Birner P. Schindl M. Obermaier A. Breitenecker G. Obermaier G. Clin. Cancer Res. 2001; 7: 1661-1668PubMed Google Scholar). Necrotic areas, most likely induced by hypoxia, were more frequently observed in poorly differentiated ovarian tumor as compared with well differentiated carcinomas. Stronger expression of HIF-1α in well differentiated ovarian tumors than poorly differentiated tumors suggested that overexpression of HIF-1α in these tumors cannot be attributed to hypoxia alone. Birner et al. (37Birner P. Schindl M. Obermaier A. Breitenecker G. Obermaier G. Clin. Cancer Res. 2001; 7: 1661-1668PubMed Google Scholar) further demonstrated a correlation between HIF-1α overexpression and increased vascularization in human ovarian cancer. In this regard, we previously reported (12Salani D., Di Castro V. Nicotra M.R. Rosanò L. Tecce R. Venuti A. Natali P.G. Bagnato A. Am. J. Pathol. 2000; 157: 1537-1547Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (179) Google Scholar) that ET-1 was expressed in 84% of the ovarian carcinomas and demonstrated for the first time a strong correlation between ET-1 and neovascularization and VEGF expression. These findings suggest that ETAR activation by ET-1 participates in ovarian carcinoma pathogenesis, driving tumor cells growth and angiogenesis in a paracrine fashion by inducing the expression and secretion of VEGF acting on HIF-1α. Because increased HIF-1 activity may also influence tumor progression independently from its regulation of VEGF expression (38Ryan H.E. Poloni M. MeVulty W. Elson D. Garsmann M. Arbeit J. Johnson R.S. Cancer Res. 2000; 60: 4010-4015PubMed Google Scholar), inhibition of HIF-1α could represent a novel approach to cancer therapy especially for those cancer types, such as ovarian tumors, in which a high level of HIF-1 overexpression is correlated with mortality. Our findings, besides giving further insights into the role of the ET-1 receptor in cancer, may be clinically relevant. Addition of a specific ETAR antagonist, BQ 123, blocked the ET-1-induced up-regulation of VEGF expression and secretion as well as the ET-1-induced activation of HIF-1 transcription complex, indicating a direct involvement of ETAR in the control of tumor angiogenesis. Because the regulation of VEGF production is a critical event in tumor angiogenesis, one can envision that under pathological conditions such as cancer, ET-1 may be up-regulated by hypoxia (3Yamashita K. Discher D.J., Hu, J. Bishopric N.H. Webster K.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 12645-12653Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (291) Google Scholar) and that ET-1, in turn, might exert an angiogenic effect increasing VEGF production through the HIF-1α-dependent mechanism. Thus, under hypoxic conditions ET-1 cooperates with hypoxia-amplifying HIF-1α stability and VEGF production. The present studies indicating ET-1 as a novel regulator of HIF-1α stability added further information on the overall importance of ET-1/ETAR in regulating tumor angiogenesis. Thus ETAR blockade in ovarian tumor cells prevents the growth-promoting activity of ET-1 by inhibiting cell proliferation (8Bagnato A. Tecce R., Di Castro V. Catt K.J. Cancer Res. 1997; 57: 1306-1311PubMed Google Scholar) and survival (9Del Bufalo D., Di Castro V. Biroccio A. Varmi M. Salani D. Rosanò L. Trisciuoglio D. Spinella F. Bagnato A. Mol. Pharmacol. 2002; 61: 524-532Crossref PubMed Scopus (139) Google Scholar) and cell migration and invasiveness (10Rosanò L. Varmi M. Salani D., Di Castro V. Spinella F. Natali P.G. Bagnato A. Cancer Res. 2001; 61: 8340-8346PubMed Google Scholar) but also the VEGF-mediated angiogenesis. In conclusion, these results defined a novel mechanism that could act with a hypoxic independent pathway and/or could enhance the hypoxic dependent molecular machinery resulting in tumor angiogenesis and identified ETAR as novel target for the development of anti-angiogenic therapies. We thank Marco Varmi for excellent technical assistance and Maria Vincenza Sarcone for secretarial assistance.

Mammalian cells contain potent activity for removal of 3′-phosphoglycolates from single-stranded oligomers and from 3′ overhangs of DNA double strand breaks, but no specific enzyme has been implicated in such removal. Fractionated human whole-cell extracts contained an activity, which in the presence of EDTA, catalyzed removal of glycolate from phosphoglycolate at a single-stranded 3′ terminus to leave a 3′-phosphate, reminiscent of the human tyrosyl-DNA phosphodiesterase hTdp1. Recombinant hTdp1, as well asSaccharomyces cerevisiae Tdp1, catalyzed similar removal of glycolate, although less efficiently than removal of tyrosine. Moreover, glycolate-removing activity could be immunodepleted from the fractionated extracts by antiserum to hTdp1. When a plasmid containing a double strand break with a 3′-phosphoglycolate on a 3-base 3′ overhang was incubated in human cell extracts, phosphoglycolate processing proceeded rapidly for the first few minutes but then slowed dramatically, suggesting that the single-stranded overhangs gradually became sequestered and inaccessible to hTdp1. The results suggest a role for hTdp1 in repair of free radical-mediated DNA double strand breaks bearing terminally blocked 3′ overhangs. Biol. 1985; 32: 115-154Crossref PubMed Scopus (450) Google Scholar, 2Ward J.F. Prog. Nucleic Acid Res. Mol. Biol. 1988; 35: 95-125Crossref PubMed Scopus (1156) Google Scholar, 5Henner W.D. Rodriguez L.O. Hecht S.M. Haseltine W.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 711-713Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) that must be removed to allow fill-in of gaps by DNA polymerase and final religation by DNA ligase. While the human apurinic/apyrimidinic endonuclease Ape1 can remove PGs, albeit inefficiently, from blunt and recessed 3′ ends of DSBs (6Suh D. Wilson III D.M. Povirk L.F. Nucleic Acids Res. 1997; 25: 2495-2500Crossref PubMed Scopus (149) Google Scholar), PGs on 3′ overhangs are highly resistant to this enzyme (6Suh D. Wilson III D.M. Povirk L.F. Nucleic Acids Res. 1997; 25: 2495-2500Crossref PubMed Scopus (149) Google Scholar, 7Chaudhry M.A. Dedon P.C. Wilson D.M. Demple B. Weinfeld M. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1999; 57: 531-538Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar). Nevertheless, in mammalian cell extracts, PGs on 3′ overhangs of DSBs are removed by an as yet unidentified activity, and a fraction of such DSBs are accurately rejoined by Ku-mediated end alignment, gap-filling, and ligation (8Chen S. Inamdar K.V. Pfeiffer P. Feldmann E. Hannah M.F., Yu, Y. Lee J.W. Zhou T. Lees-Miller S.P. Povirk L.F. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 24323-24330Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (98) Google Scholar). The yeast tyrosyl-DNA phosphodiesterase scTdp1 was isolated fromSaccharomyces cerevisiae as an activity that hydrolyzes the phosphodiester bond linking tyrosine to a 3′ DNA end (9Yang S.W. Burgin A.B., Jr. Huizenga B.N. Robertson C.A. Yao K.C. Nash H.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 11534-11539Crossref PubMed Scopus (323) Google Scholar). Such linkages are formed as intermediates in DNA relaxation by topoisomerase I and in DNA cleavage and reunion by various recombinases. These intermediates can become trapped if the process is interrupted, for example, by a topoisomerase inhibitor or by collision with a replication fork. The hypersensitivity of tdp1Δ yeast to topoisomerase I-mediated DNA damage (10Pouliot J.J. Yao K.C. Robertson C.A. Nash H.A. Science. 1999; 286: 552-555Crossref PubMed Scopus (305) Google Scholar) suggests a critical role for scTdp1 in repair of such lesions. A human homologue with similar 3′-phosphotyrosyl-processing activity, hTdp1, was cloned by homology to scTdp1 and was eventually shown to have some homology to the phospholipase D superfamily of phosphodiesterases (11Interthal H. Pouliot J.J. Champoux J.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001; 98: 12009-12014Crossref PubMed Scopus (233) Google Scholar). Yeast and human Tdp1 differ from other activities for processing blocked 3′ ends in that they leave a 3′-phosphate rather than a 3′-hydroxyl. A 3′-phosphate could then be removed by polynucleotide kinase/phosphatase (human PNKP (12Jilani A. Slack C. Matheos D. Zannis-Hadjopoulos M. Lasko D.D. J. Cell. Biochem. 1999; 73: 188-203Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar, 13Karimi-Busheri F. Daly G. Robins P. Canas B. Pappin D.J. Sgouros J. Miller G.G. Fakhrai H. Davis E.M., Le Beau M.M. Weinfeld M. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 24187-24194Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (196) Google Scholar) or Schizosaccharomyces pombe Pnk1 (14Meijer M. Karimi-Busheri F. Huang T.Y. Weinfeld M. Young D. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 4050-4055Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar)) or in S. cerevisiae by the 3′-phosphatase Tpp1 (15Vance J.R. Wilson T.E. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2001; 21: 7191-7198Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar). As reported below, comparison of the properties of hTdp1 with those of 3′-PG-processing activities in human cell extracts suggests that a major portion, if not all, of the processing of 3′-PGs on DSBs with 3′ overhangs is attributable to hTdp1. Gel filtration was performed on a prepacked 1.6 × 60-cm (190 ml of bed volume) Sephacryl S-300 column (Amersham Biosciences). The column was loaded with 1 ml of undiluted cell extract (∼10 mg), and elution buffer (20 mm Tris-HCl, 0.1 m potassium acetate, 0.5 mm EDTA, 1 mm dithiothreitol, 20% (v/v) glycerol) was applied with a peristaltic pump at 0.14 ml/min at 9 °C. A280 was recorded, and 2-ml fractions were collected and stored at 4 °C. Fractions showed no loss of PG-processing activity for at least 2 weeks. Phosphocellulose ion exchange chromatography was performed on a column of 1 cm diameter and 1 ml of bed volume. The column was loaded with 1 ml of undiluted cell extract and eluted with three 1-ml aliquots of the elution buffer, and ∼1-ml fractions collected by gravity flow. This procedure was repeated using the same buffer supplemented with 0.15 and 0.5 m KCl. End-joining assays in crude extracts were carried out in 20 μl of human end-joining buffer (50 mm triethanolamine-HCl, pH 7.5, 0.5 mm magnesium acetate, 60 mm potassium acetate, 2 mm ATP, 1 mm DTT, 100 μg/ml bovine serum albumin (19Baumann P. West S.C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 14066-14070Crossref PubMed Scopus (271) Google Scholar)) containing 50 μm each dNTP, 60 μg of extract, and 3 fmol of the 3′-PG plasmid substrate. Pfeiffer P. Feldmann E. Hannah M.F., Yu, Y. Lee J.W. Zhou T. Lees-Miller S.P. Povirk L.F. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 24323-24330Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (98) Google Scholar). The extraction and chromatography buffers all contained 0.5 mm EDTA, and therefore the magnesium acetate concentration in the reactions was adjusted so that the final free Mg2+ concentration would be 0.5 mm. In some cases magnesium acetate was omitted and various concentrations of EDTA was added as indicated. Following incubation at 37 °C, the oligomeric substrate was diluted with one volume of formamide containing 40 mm EDTA and electrophoresed on 20% polyacrylamide sequencing gels. The plasmid substrate was ethanol-precipitated in the presence of 2 μg of tRNA, cut withXhoI, again precipitated and subjected to gel electrophoresis. Sgouros J. Miller G.G. Fakhrai H. Davis E.M., Le Beau M.M. Weinfeld M. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 24187-24194Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (196) Google Scholar). Nucleic Acids Res. 1997; 25: 2495-2500Crossref PubMed Scopus (149) Google Scholar). Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001; 98: 12009-12014Crossref PubMed Scopus (233) Google Scholar). Samples (0.1 mg) were injected into rabbits according to the ResGen standard protocol, and bleeds were taken every 4 weeks. Experiments described here were performed with the week 16 bleed. Samples containing 95 μl of undiluted fractionated extract and 5 μl of undiluted or diluted hTdp1 antiserum were rotated at 4 °C for 3 h. Protein-A-Sepharose beads were prewashed with end-joining buffer, and then 20 μl of beads were added to each sample. The samples were rotated for 1 h at 4 °C and centrifuged at 1500 rpm for 5 min. To assess PG-processing activity, 20 fmol of 3′-PG 14-mer were added to 5 μl of undiluted supernatant and incubated for 2 h at 37 °C. Aliquots (20 μl) of fractions from Sephacryl S-300 chromatography were heat-denatured and electrophoresed on 10% SDS-polyacrylamide gels, and proteins were electroblotted onto nitrocellulose. Blots were probed with polyclonal rabbit antisera to hTdp1 (1:1000 dilution) or Ku70 and Ku80 (1:2000, Chemicon International, Temecula, CA, no. 1358 and no. 1357, respectively) and then with peroxidase-conjugated goat anti-rabbit antibody (1:10,000, Kirkegaard & Perry, Gaithersburg, MD). Blots were developed with an SuperSignal Chemiluminescence kit (Pierce) and autoradiographed. To ensure that proteins recognized by hTdp1 antiserum were in fact hTdp1, antiserum at a 200:1 dilution was incubated for 4 h in the presence of 0.3 μg/ml recombinant hTdp1 for 1 h; this pretreatment completely eliminated detection of the putative hTdp1 bands. Previous work showed that human,Xenopus, and hamster cell extracts are capable of processing DSBs bearing PG termini on 3′-overhangs (8Chen S. Inamdar K.V. Pfeiffer P. Feldmann E. Hannah M.F., Yu, Y. Lee J.W. Zhou T. Lees-Miller S.P. Povirk L.F. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 24323-24330Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (98) Google Scholar). In a typical end-joining experiment in human whole-cell extracts (Fig.2A) ∼5% of a substrate with partially cohesive 3′ overhangs (Fig. 1D) was converted to accurately joined products (indicated by the 43- and 24-bp fragments) by a mechanism involving PG removal, alignment of partially cohesive 3′ overhangs, fill-in of the one-base gap in each strand, and ligation. The intermediate step of PG removal could be clearly seen as a band of slightly slower mobility than the initial substrate (15-mer band in Fig. 2). A kinetic study showed that PG removal proceeded rapidly at first, with ∼30% removal in the first 10 min, but then slowed dramatically (Fig.2C). The failure of the reaction to go to completion was not due to instability of PG-removing enzyme(s) because new substrate added 1 h after the start of the incubation also showed rapid initial PG removal (not shown). Moreover, as described below, the same extracts were able to effect rapid, quantitative removal of PG from a single-stranded oligomer. Thus, the kinetics of PG processing with the plasmid substrate suggest that the 3′ overhangs gradually became resistant to PG-processing activities. Footprinting studies 2K. V. Inamdar and L. F. Povik, unpublished data. suggest that this resistance may be attributable to sequestration of DNA ends by repair complexes containing DNA-PK, which are formed within 20 min of substrate addition. When extracts were treated with the DNA-PK inhibitor wortmannin prior to addition of substrate, end joining was blocked entirely but PG removal was reduced only slightly. These results, as well as the complete removal of PG termini from the same substrate in Ku-deficient xrs6 cells (8Chen S. Inamdar K.V. Pfeiffer P. Feldmann E. Hannah M.F., Yu, Y. Lee J.W. Zhou T. Lees-Miller S.P. Povirk L.F. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 24323-24330Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (98) Google Scholar), suggest that PG processing on 3′ overhangs does not require prior formation of the DNA-PK repair complex on DNA ends and may be attributable to a diffusible enzyme in the extracts. Surprisingly, substantial PG removal, but very little end joining, occurred even in the absence of added Mg2+ (Fig. 2B). In an attempt to identify candidate enzymes for processing of protruding 3′-PG termini, the same substrate was treated with purified recombinant Ape1, the only specific mammalian enzyme known to remove 3′-PG termini (24Demple B. Harrison L. Ann. Rev. Biochem. 1994; 63: 915-948Crossref PubMed Scopus (1282) Google Scholar). However, just as reported previously for analogous oligomeric substrates (6Suh D. Wilson III D.M. Povirk L.F. Nucleic Acids Res. 1997; 25: 2495-2500Crossref PubMed Scopus (149) Google Scholar), Ape1 had no detectable effect on the PG-terminated 3′ overhang (Fig. 3A). Studies of Ku structure and function suggest that in cells and cell extracts, Ku stabilizes alignment of the overhangs of two DSB ends to form what is essentially a duplex substrate with closely opposed 3′-PG-terminated single strand breaks (8Chen S. Inamdar K.V. Pfeiffer P. Feldmann E. Hannah M.F., Yu, Y. Lee J.W. Zhou T. Lees-Miller S.P. Povirk L.F. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 24323-24330Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (98) Google Scholar, 25Walker J.R. Corpina R.A. Goldberg J. Nature. 2001; 412: 607-614Crossref PubMed Scopus (837) Google Scholar), a structure that might then be susceptible to PG removal by Ape1. However, neither Ku nor DNA-PK holoenzyme (Ku plus DNA-PKcs) rendered the overhanging 3′-PG termini susceptible to Ape1 (Fig. 3A). Another possible candidate for catalyzing PG removal on a 3′ overhang was the human polynucleotide kinase/phosphatase PNKP, which removes 3′-phosphates from both single- and double-stranded DNA substrates (12Jilani A. Slack C. Matheos D. Zannis-Hadjopoulos M. Lasko D.D. J. Cell. Biochem. 1999; 73: 188-203Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar,13Karimi-Busheri F. Daly G. Robins P. Canas B. Pappin D.J. Sgouros J. Miller G.G. Fakhrai H. Davis E.M., Le Beau M.M. Weinfeld M. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 24187-24194Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (196) Google Scholar). Indeed, a plant phosphodiesterase with homology to PNKP has been reported to have weak PG-removing activity (26Betti M. Petrucco S. Bolchi A. Dieci G. Ottonello S. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 18038-18045Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). As shown in Fig.3B, PNKP alone had no effect on the plasmid substrate with a PG-terminated 3′ overhang, but in the presence of purified human Ku, PNKP appeared to catalyze substantial conversion of 3′-PG to 3′-hydroxyl termini. However, Ku alone converted an approximately equal fraction of the 3′-PG to a product of very slightly reduced mobility. The mobility of this band and its apparent conversion to a 3′-hydroxyl by PNKP is consistent with a 3′-phosphate, presumably formed by removal of glycolate from the 3′-PG terminus (the same band can be seen, though less clearly, in the Ku-treated samples in Fig. 3A). These results suggested that PNKP itself did not process 3′-PG termini but that either Ku or a contaminant in the placental Ku was capable of converting 3′-PG to 3′-phosphate termini. In an initial attempt to purify the protein(s) responsible for 3′-PG processing on 3′ overhangs, human whole-cell extracts were fractionated on phosphocellulose, and fractions were tested for effects on two substrates: a 3′-PG 14-mer (Fig. 1B; used as a surrogate for a 3′ overhang) and an oligomeric duplex with a central one-base gap bearing 3′-PG and 5′-phosphate termini (Fig. 1A). Activity for 3′-PG-to-3′-hydroxyl conversion in the gapped duplex substrate eluted primarily in the 0.5 m KCl fraction (Fig.4A), which has been reported to contain the bulk of DNA end-joining activity (19Baumann P. West S.C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 14066-14070Crossref PubMed Scopus (271) Google Scholar). However, activity for conversion of 3′-PG to 3′-hydroxyl termini on the single-strand substrate eluted primarily in the 0.15 m KCl fraction (Fig.4B), suggesting that the activity was distinct from the activity that acts on 3′-PGs at internal gaps in duplex substrates (presumably Ape1/HAP1). In addition to the band corresponding to a 3′-hydroxyl terminus, there was, for samples treated with the 0.15m KCl fractions, substantial amounts of the putative 3′-phosphate band seen in assays with Ku, and indeed for the earliest-eluting 0.15 m KCl fraction this band was more prominent than the 3′-hydroxyl band. One candidate for catalyzing conversion of 3′-PG to 3′-phosphate termini would be the human tyrosyl-DNA phosphodiesterase hTdp1. hTdp1 catalyzes cleavage of the diester bond between a terminal 3′-phosphate of DNA and tyrosine (11Interthal H. Pouliot J.J. Champoux J.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001; 98: 12009-12014Crossref PubMed Scopus (233) Google Scholar) and is the only mammalian diesterase reported to convert any type of blocked 3′ DNA terminus to a 3′-phosphate. If the PG removal catalyzed by whole-cell extracts involved sequential removal of glycolate and phosphate by hTdp1 and PNKP, respectively, then it should be possible to trap the 3′-phosphate intermediate by addition of EDTA since PNKP requires Mg2+ (12Jilani A. Slack C. Matheos D. Zannis-Hadjopoulos M. Lasko D.D. J. Cell. Biochem. 1999; 73: 188-203Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar, 13Karimi-Busheri F. Daly G. Robins P. Canas B. Pappin D.J. Sgouros J. Miller G.G. Fakhrai H. Davis E.M., Le Beau M.M. Weinfeld M. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 24187-24194Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (196) Google Scholar), whereas hTdp1 does not (11Interthal H. Pouliot J.J. Champoux J.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001; 98: 12009-12014Crossref PubMed Scopus (233) Google Scholar). Indeed, whereas in the presence of Mg2+ a 3′-PG 14-mer was extensively degraded in unfractionated whole-cell extracts, at 1 mm EDTA a full-length 3′-hydroxyl oligomer was produced, and at 5–40 mm EDTA the putative phosphate band was the predominant product (Fig. 5A). These results suggest that the 3′-phosphatase and exonuclease activities were both much more sensitive to EDTA than the glycolate-removing activity. EDTA also inhibited 3′-hydroxyl formation by the 0.15 m KCl phosphocellulose fraction and trapped the same 3′-phosphate intermediate (Fig. 5B). Similar formation of 3′-phosphate products was catalyzed in the presence of EDTA by extracts of Ku-deficient xrs6 hamster cells, suggesting that the glycolate-removing activity, despite its copurification with Ku, was not Ku and did not require Ku (Fig. 5B). To determine whether the activity for removal of glycolate from single-stranded 3′-PG termini in human cell extracts might be hTdp1, the extracts were fractionated by gel filtration chromatography on Sephacryl S-300 (Fig. 6). A prominent peak of glycolate-removing activity coeluted with hTdp1 protein as detected with hTdp1 antiserum at a position approximately midway between the 44- and 158-kDa markers. In the presence of 5 mm EDTA, this fraction catalyzed the 3′-PG-to-3′-phosphate conversion with no detectable formation of 3′-hydroxyl. Titration of the activity in the peak fraction showed that it processed a 3′-phosphotyrosine oligomer 8-fold more efficiently than the PG-terminated 3′-overhang (Fig.7A), consistent with its identification as hTdp1. The single-stranded 3′-PG 14-mer was processed about 2-fold less efficiently than the 3′ overhang (not shown).Figure 7Relative efficiencies of native and recombinant end-processing activities. A 3′-phosphotyrosine 18-mer (▴), a 3′-PG 14-mer (▪), or a plasmid with a PG-terminated 3′-overhang (●,○) were treated with Sephacryl fraction 30 from human whole-cell extracts (A), recombinant hTdp1 (B, C), or recombinant scTdp (D) in the presence (open symbols) or absence (closed symbols) of Ku (75 ng). Each substrate was incubated at 37 °C for 2 h in a 5-μl reaction containing 5 mm EDTA and no Mg2+. Conversion to a 3′-phosphate was assessed by denaturing gel electrophoresis.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) The purified Ku from human placenta was also found to contain substantial 3′-phosphotyrosine-processing activity. Assays of various fractions from the MonoQ chromatography step in Ku purification (see Ref. 21Chan D.W. Mody C.H. Ting N.S. Lees-Miller S.P. Biochem. Cell Biol. 1996; 74: 67-73Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar) showed that the peak of phosphotyrosine-processing activity did not precisely coincide with Ku, but the two did overlap (data not shown). All of these results are consistent with the glycolate-removing activity in placental Ku (Fig. 3) being attributable to contaminating hTdp1 (Mr = 68,500), which comigrates with Ku70 on denaturing polyacrylamide gels and thus would not have been detected as a contaminant. To further assess the possibility that PG processing in extracts might be due to hTdp1, the 3′-PG substrates were treated with recombinant hTdp1 or scTdp1 (Fig. 8). Similar to the fractionated extracts, both recombinant tyrosyl-DNA phosphodiesterases converted 3′-PG termini to 3′-phosphate termini in either the presence or absence of Mg2+. In each case, the putative 3′-phosphate terminus could be converted to a 3′-hydroxyl by PNKP. To determine the efficiency of the processing of 3′-PG termini by hTdp1, a 3′-phosphotyrosine DNA oligomer and the DSB substrate with a PG-terminated 3′ overhang were treated with various concentrations of the enzyme (Figs. 7B and 8B). The 3′-PG substrate required an ∼80-fold greater concentration of hTdp1 for half-maximal conversion than did the 3′-phosphotyrosine oligomer (Fig.7B), more than would have been expected based on the activities in fractionated extracts (Fig. 7A). Processing of the 3′-PG 14-mer required similarly high concentrations of hTdp1 (not shown). To assess whether this rather weak PG-processing activity might have been attributable to a bacterial contaminant rather than to hTdp1, the 3′-PG 14-mer was treated with various dilutions of crude bacterial lysates from both the hTDP1-overexpressing strain and the strain transfected with an empty vector (Fig. 8B). Only the lysate from hTDP1-overexpressing bacteria catalyzed conversion of 3′-PG to 3′-phosphate termini, confirming that the activity was attributable to hTdp1. The low PG-processing efficiency of the recombinant hTdp1 also raises the question of whether the PG-processing activity in human cell extracts, despite its functional similarity, might be some enzyme other than hTdp1. To address this question, the peak fraction of PG-processing activity from Sephacryl chromatography was immunodepleted with rabbit antiserum to hTdp1 (Fig. 9). At a 1/20 dilution, this antiserum completely eliminated 3′-PG-processing activity, whereas preimmune serum did not. These results are consistent with hTdp1 being the primary 3′-PG-processing activity for 3′ overhangs in human cell extracts. In contrast to hTdp1, recombinant scTdp1 processed the 3′-PG oligomer almost as efficiently as the 3′-phosphotyrosyl oligomer (Fig. 7D). The copurification of hTdp1 with human placental Ku raised the possibility that Ku might recruit hTdp1 to DNA ends. To examine this possibility, hTdp1-catalyzed glycolate removal from the plasmid with a protruding 3′-PG terminus was assayed in the presence or absence of 15 μg/ml recombinant Ku, which unlike native placental Ku was free of any PG-processing activity. As shown in Fig. 8C, the effect of Ku was inhibitory, decreasing the susceptibility of the substrate to hTdp1-mediated processing by approximately 16-fold, presumably because Ku binding rendered DNA ends less accessible. Thus, there was no evidence for recruitment of hTdp1 to DNA ends by Ku, although it is possible that the recombinant proteins differ from the native proteins in ways that interfere with such interactions. DSBs induced by the radiomimetic antibiotics neocarzinostatin and calicheamicin typically have PG-terminated 3′ overhangs at one end of the break (3Povirk L.F. Mutat. Res. 1996; 355: 71-89Crossref PubMed Scopus (332) Google Scholar, 4Dedon P.C. Goldberg I.H. Chem. Res. Toxicol. 1992; 5: 311-332Crossref PubMed Scopus (229) Google Scholar). About half of radiation-induced strand breaks also have 3′-PG termini (5Henner W.D. Rodriguez L.O. Hecht S.M. Haseltine W.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 711-713Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), and many of these are presumably on 3′ overhangs of DSBs. In the repair of such lesions, removal of the 3′-PG termini must necessarily precede any polymerase-mediated gap filling and/or religation of the DSB. However, while the human apurinic/apyrimidinic endonuclease Ape1 can remove PGs from internal breaks in double-stranded DNA (24Demple B. Harrison L. Ann. Rev. Biochem. 1994; 63: 915-948Crossref PubMed Scopus (1282) Google Scholar), PGs on blunt and recessed 3′ termini of DSBs are relatively resistant to this enzyme, and PGs on 3′ overhangs are completely refractory (6Suh D. Wilson III D.M. Povirk L.F. Nucleic Acids Res. 1997; 25: 2495-2500Crossref PubMed Scopus (149) Google Scholar). The human polynucleotide kinase/phosphatase PNKP, which removes 3′ phosphates from single-stranded 3′ termini (12Jilani A. Slack C. Matheos D. Zannis-Hadjopoulos M. Lasko D.D. J. Cell. Biochem. 1999; 73: 188-203Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar, 13Karimi-Busheri F. Daly G. Robins P. Canas B. Pappin D.J. Sgouros J. Miller G.G. Fakhrai H. Davis E.M., Le Beau M.M. Weinfeld M. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 24187-24194Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (196) Google Scholar), also has no detectable effect on 3′-PGs (Fig. 3), just as was previously reported for rat polynucleotide kinase/phosphatase (27Habraken Y. Verly W.G. Eur. J. Biochem. 1988; 171: 59-66Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar). The susceptibility of 3′-PGs toEscherichia coli exonuclease I (28Sandigursky M. Franklin W.A. Radiat. Res. 1993; 135: 229-233Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar) raises the possibility that PGs on 3′ overhangs might be removed by a mammalian 3′→5′ exonuclease. However, DNase III, which is the dominant 3′→5′ exonuclease in mammalian cell extracts, has no detectable effect on any 3′-PG substrates (29Inamdar K.V., Yu, Y. Povirk L.F. Radiat. Res. 2002; 157: 306-311Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar). The Wrn1 and Mre11 3′→5′ exonucleases are also unlikely candidates because 3′ overhangs, even if unblocked, are resistant to these enzymes (30Kamath-Loeb A.S. Shen J.C. Loeb L.A. Fry M. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 34145-34150Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (193) Google Scholar, 31Paull T.T. Gellert M. Mol. Cell. 1998; 1: 969-979Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (691) Google Scholar, 32Huang S. Beresten S., Li, B. Oshima J. Ellis N.A. Campisi J. Nucleic Acids Res. 2000. 2002; 28: 2396-2405Crossref Scopus (130) Google Scholar). Nevertheless, PGs on overhanging 3′ termini clearly are processed in Xenopus, human, and hamster cell extracts (8Chen S. Inamdar K.V. Pfeiffer P. Feldmann E. Hannah M.F., Yu, Y. Lee J.W. Zhou T. Lees-Miller S.P. Povirk L.F. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 24323-24330Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (98) Google Scholar). Evidence for a 3′-phosphate intermediate in 3′-PG removal in human cell extracts suggested possible involvement of hTdp1, and indeed, both hTdp1 and scTdp1 were found to catalyze similar glycolate removal from a single-stranded oligomer as well as from a single strand overhang of a DSB. Failure to detect this activity in previous studies may have been due to the very small difference in electrophoretic mobility between 3′-PG and 3′-phosphate oligomers and the relative inefficiency of PG processing by recombinant hTdp1 compared with its nominal substrate, 3′-phosphotyrosine. The difference in relative preference for 3′-phosphotyrosine over 3′-PG substrates, 80-fold for purified recombinant hTdp1 versus8-fold for the native activity in extracts, raises the question of whether most of the native PG-processing activity might be attributable to some functionally similar but distinct enzyme. While this possibility has not been rigorously eliminated, it seems unlikely, as such an enzyme would have to precisely coelute from Sephacryl with hTdp1 and would have to cross-react with antibody raised to recombinant hTdp1 to explain the immunodepletion data. More likely, the different substrate preferences may be attributable to the presence of the histidine tag, differences in posttranslational modification in humanversus bacterial cells, or interactions with other proteins in the fractionated extract. It is also possible that there was a partial degradation of the recombinant protein during purification and storage that resulted in selective loss of PG-processing activity. In either case the relatively greater activity of the native enzyme toward PG termini makes a biological role in PG removal more plausible. Nevertheless, it remains possible that other more robust activities for PG removal exist in vivo but that they are degraded or otherwise inactive in extracts. It is also possible that only the initial rapid phase of PG processing is attributable to hTdp1, and that some other enzyme is responsible for the slower removal that occurs after the DNA-PK repair complex has formed on DSB ends. Thus, conclusive proof of the importance of hTdp1 in processing of terminally blocked, free radical-mediated DSBs must await construction of hTdp1-null mutants. If such a role is confirmed, the relative inefficiency of hTdp1 in PG removal may make it an attractive target for radiosensitization as a relatively modest decrease in hTdp1 activity might be sufficient to significantly inhibit the repair of radiation-induced DSBs and enhance their cytotoxicity. The dynamics of conformational isomerization are explored in a methyl-capped dipeptide, N-acetyl-tryptophan methyl amide (NATMA), using infrared-ultraviolet (IR-UV) hole-filling and IR-induced population transfer spectroscopies. IR radiation selectively excites individual NH stretch vibrational fundamentals of single conformations of the molecule in the early portions of a gas-phase expansion, and then this excited population is collisionally recooled into its conformational minima for subsequent conformation-specific detection. Efficient isomerization is induced by the IR excitation that redistributes population between the same conformations that have population in the absence of IR excitation. The quantum yields for transfer of the population into the various conformational minima depend uniquely on which conformation is excited and on which NH stretch vibration is excited within a given conformation.

The invasion of migratory cells through connective tissues involves metallo- and serine types of cell surface proteases. We show that formation of a novel protease complex, consisting of the membrane-bound prolyl peptidases seprase and dipeptidyl peptidase IV (DPPIV), at invadopodia of migratory fibroblasts is a prerequisite for cell invasion and migration on a collagenous matrix. Seprase and DPPIV form a complex on the cell surface that elicits both gelatin binding and gelatinase activities localized at invadopodia of cells migrating on collagenous fibers. The protease complex participates in the binding to gelatin and localized gelatin degradation, cellular migration, and monolayer wound closure. Serine protease inhibitors can block the gelatinase activity and the localized gelatin degradation by cells. Antibodies to the gelatin-binding domain of DPPIV reduce the cellular abilities of the proteases to degrade gelatin but do not affect cellular adhesion or spreading on type I collagen. Furthermore, expression of the seprase-DPPIV complex is restricted to migratory cells involved in wound closure in vitro and in connective tissue cells during closure of gingival wounds but not in differentiated tissue cells. Thus, we have identified cell surface proteolytic activities, which are non-metalloproteases, seprase and DPPIV, that are responsible for the tissue-invasive phenotype.

Helicobacter pylori is a widespread human pathogen that can cause gastric ulcers and cancer. To identify surface proteins that may play a role in pathogen-host interactions and represent potential targets for the control of this infection, we selectively biotinylated intact H. pylori with the hydrophilic reagent sulfosuccinimidyl-6-(biotinamido)-hexanoate and purified the labeled proteins by membrane isolation, solubilization, and affinity chromatography. After separation of 82 biotinylated proteins on two-dimensional gels, 18 were identified with comparison to proteome data and peptide mass fingerprinting. Among the identified proteins, 9 have previously been shown to be surface-exposed, 7 are associated with virulence, and 11 are highly immunogenic in infected patients. In conclusion, this generally applicable combined proteome approach facilitates the rapid identification of promising targets for the control of H. pylori and might be applicable to numerous other human pathogens although larger biotinylation reagents might be required in some cases to prevent permeation of porin channels in the outer membrane. Crabtree J.E. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 1998; 859: 96-111Crossref PubMed Scopus (60) Google Scholar, 2Telford J.L. Covacci A. Rappuoli R. Chiara P. Curr. Opin. However, in 10% of those infected severe pathological consequences develop including gastric and duodenal ulcer, atrophic gastritis, adenocarcinoma, or mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma. The surface of H. pylori provides an important interface for pathogen-host interactions including flagella-driven motility in the stomach mucus layer, local buffering of stomach acid by urease, adhesion to gastric epithelial cells mediated by several adhesins including BabA (3Ilver D. Nucleic Acids Res. 1999; 27: 3325-3333Crossref PubMed Scopus (150) Google Scholar), translocation of CagA into host cells via the type IV secretion apparatus encoded in the Cag1(cytotoxin-associated genes) pathogenicity island (6Segal E.D.
