Rossant J. Yamaguchi T.P. Gertsentein M., Fu Wu, X. Breitman M.L. Schuh A.C. Nature. 1995; 376: 62-66Crossref PubMed Scopus (3338) Google Scholar, 2Millauer B. Shawver L.K. Plate K.H. Risau W. Ullrich A. Nature. 1994; 367: 576-579Crossref PubMed Scopus (1160) Google Scholar, 3Kim K.J., Li, B. Winer J. Armanini M. Gillett N. Phillips H.S. Ferrara N. Nature. 1993; 362: 841-844Crossref PubMed Scopus (3337) Google Scholar). Angiogenesis is considered to be an essential requirement for tumor growth and metastasis and numerous other human pathological disorders ranging from arthritis to diabetes (4Risau W. Nature. 1997; 386: 671-674Crossref PubMed Scopus (4805) Google Scholar, 5Folkman J. D'Amore P Cell. 1996; 87: 1153-1155Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1096) Google Scholar, 6Carmeliet P. Jain R.K. Nature. 2000; 407: 249-257Crossref PubMed Scopus (7394) Google Scholar). Activation of VEGFR-2 elicits endothelial cell proliferation, migration, differentiation, and permeability to macromolecules (7Waltenberger J. Calaesson-Welsh L. Siegbahn A. Shibuya M. Heldin C.-H. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 26988-26995Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 8Rahimi N. Dayanir V. Lashkari K. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 16986-16992Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (197) Google Scholar). The signaling pathways that feature the activity of VEGFR-2 are largely unknown. As with other receptor tyrosine kinases, binding of its ligand induces receptor dimerization, leading to autophosphorylation of tyrosine residues in the cytoplasmic domain of VEGFR-2. Many tyrosines in the cytoplasmic domain of VEGFR-2 have been shown to be phosphorylated in response to ligand binding to the extracellular domain of VEGFR-2 (10Dougher-Vermazen M. Hulmes J.D. Bohlen P. Terman B.I. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1994; 205: 728-738Crossref PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar, 11Takahashi T. Yamaguchi S. Chida K. Shibuya M. EMBO J. 2001; 20: 2768-2778Crossref PubMed Scopus (599) Google Scholar). The autophosphorylation sites in general are either involved in the regulation of kinase activity or serve as binding sites for SH2- and phosphotyrosine binding-containing signaling proteins (12Pawson T. Nature. 1995; 373: 573-580Crossref PubMed Scopus (2222) Google Scholar). Phosphorylation of tyrosines 1054 and 1059 in the activation loop of VEGFR-2 has been shown to be required for its intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity (13Kendall R.L. Rutledge R.Z. Mao X. Tebben A.J. Hungate R.W. Thomas K.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 6453-6460Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (111) Google Scholar). Similarly, replacement of lysine 866 residue with arginine in the ATP binding pocket of VEGFR-2 abolishes its intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity (14Dayanir V. Meyer R.D. Lashkari K. Rahimi N. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 17686-17692Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar). This suggests that the kinase activation of VEGFR-2 depends on its intrinsic kinase activity. In addition, ligand stimulation also causes many other tyrosine sites mainly outside of the kinase domain to be phosphorylated. These phosphotyrosine sites along with their surrounding amino acids, act as docking sites for SH2 or phosphotyrosine binding domain-containing proteins (12Pawson T. Nature. 1995; 373: 573-580Crossref PubMed Scopus (2222) Google Scholar). For instance, recently we have shown that tyrosines 799 and 1173 of mouse VEGFR-2 act as binding sites for phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase. Replacement of these tyrosine sites with phenylalanine impairs the ability of VEGFR-2 to bind phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase. Noticeably, mutations of these tyrosine sites do not influence the intrinsic kinase activity or ligand-dependent autophosphorylation of the VEGFR-2 (14Dayanir V. Meyer R.D. Lashkari K. Rahimi N. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 17686-17692Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar). In recent years, it has been suggested that in addition to their catalytic domains, other tyrosine sites located outside the catalytic domains of receptor tyrosine kinases also contribute to full activation. For instance, tyrosine residues located in the juxtamembrane domain of PDGFR-β, EGF receptor, and Eph receptor are required for their full catalytic activation (16Ataliotis P. Symes K. Chou M.M., Ho, L. Mercola M. Development. 1995; 121: 3099-3110PubMed Google Scholar, 17Mori S. Ronnstrand L. Yokote K. Engstrom A. Courtneidge S.A. Claesson-Welsh L. Heldin C.H. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 2257-2264Crossref PubMed Scopus (295) Google Scholar, 18Zisch A.H. Kalo M.S. Chong L.D. Pasquale E.B. Oncogene. 1998; 16: 2657-2670Crossref PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar). Mutation of tyrosines 579 and 581 to phenylalanine in the juxtamembrane domain of PDGFR-β abolishes its ligand-dependent kinase activation and its ability to associate with the signaling proteins such as Src, PLCγ1, and RasGAP (17Mori S. Ronnstrand L. Yokote K. Engstrom A. Courtneidge S.A. Claesson-Welsh L. Heldin C.H. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 2257-2264Crossref PubMed Scopus (295) Google Scholar, 19Baxter R.M. Secrist J.P. Vaillancourt R.R. Kazlauskas A. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 17050-17055Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar). To date, the molecular mechanisms responsible for contribution of these tyrosine sites to receptor activation are not well understood. Until recently, it has been thought that activity of Src family kinases is required for the ligand-dependent kinase activation of PDGFR-β, since mutation of Src binding sites, tyrosines 579 and 581, on the PDGFR-β significantly reduces the kinase activity of PDGFR-β (17Mori S. Ronnstrand L. Yokote K. Engstrom A. Courtneidge S.A. Claesson-Welsh L. Heldin C.H. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 2257-2264Crossref PubMed Scopus (295) Google Scholar, 19Baxter R.M. Secrist J.P. Vaillancourt R.R. Kazlauskas A. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 17050-17055Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar). A more recent study demonstrated that Src family kinases are not responsible for the loss of kinase activity of PDGFR-β, since this receptor is fully functional and highly autophosphorylated after PDGF stimulation in fibroblast cells obtained from the triple knockout of Src family (Src, Yes, Fyn) kinases (20Klinghoffer R.A. Sachsenmaier C. Cooper J.A. Soriano P. EMBO J. 1999; 18: 2459-2471Crossref PubMed Scopus (646) Google Scholar). Together, these studies suggest that tyrosine residues located outside the kinase domain of receptor tyrosine kinases also play a crucial role in the ligand-stimulated kinase activation of receptor tyrosine kinases. We report here the identification of a unique and novel tyrosine residue in the carboxyl domain of VEGFR-2 responsible for full autophosphorylation of VEGFR-2, its ability to activate VEGFR-2-associated signal transduction molecules, and biological responses in endothelial cells. Our findings suggest that phosphorylation of tyrosine 1212 on VEGFR-2 may serve as a key regulatory mechanism for modulation of kinase activation of VEGFR-2 and thus angiogenesis. Porcine aortic endothelial (PAE) cells expressing CKR and mutant receptors including F1173/CKR and F1212/CKR were established by a retroviral system as described previously (14Dayanir V. Meyer R.D. Lashkari K. Rahimi N. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 17686-17692Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar). Briefly, cDNA encoding for CKR, mutant receptors, Src, and kinase-dead Src (Src/KD) were cloned into retroviral vectors and transfected into 293-GPG cells. Viral supernatants were collected for 7 days, concentrated by centrifugation, and used as previously described (21Ory D.S. Neugeboren B.A. Mulligan R.C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 11400-11406Crossref PubMed Scopus (798) Google Scholar). SYF cells were kindly provided by R. Klinghoffer from P. Soriano's laboratory (Fred Huchinson Cancer Center, Seattle, WA). The VEGFR-2 chimera (CKR) was used as a template to construct the mutations. CKR was subcloned into pGEMT cloning vector, and site-directed mutagenesis was carried out using the PCR-based site-directed mutagenesis method (22Horton M. Gene (Amst.). 1987; 77: 61-68Crossref Scopus (2634) Google Scholar). Site-directed mutagenesis primers for replacement of tyrosine 1173 described previously (14Dayanir V. Meyer R.D. Lashkari K. Rahimi N. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 17686-17692Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar). Upstream and downstream primers for making F1212 were AAATTCCATTTTGACAACACA and TGTGTTGTCAAAATGGAATTT, respectively. To generate E1212/CKR, the same primers were used, but TTT encoding for Phe was replaced with GAA encoding Glu. The resultant mutations were verified by sequencing and were subsequently cloned into pLNCX2 vector by NotI and SalI sites. PAE cells expressing CKR and CKR mutants were grown in semiconfluent culture conditions in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium containing 10% fetal bovine serum supplemented with glutamate, penicillin, and streptomycin and serum-starved overnight in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium. Cells were left either resting or stimulated with 40 ng/ml CSF-1 for 10 min at 37 °C. Cells were washed twice with H/S buffer (25 mm HEPES, pH 7.4, 150 mm NaCl, 2 mm Na3VO4) and lysed in lysis buffer (EB; 10 mm Tris-HCl, 10% glycerol, pH 7.4, 5 mm EDTA, 50 mm NaCl, 50 mm NaF, 1% Triton X-100, 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 2 mm Na3VO4, and 20 μg/ml aprotinin). Proteins were immunoprecipitated by using appropriate antibodies. Immunocomplexes were bound to protein A-Sepharose and washed three times with 1.0 ml of EB. Immunoprecipitates were resolved on an SDS-PAGE gel, and the proteins were transferred to Immobilon membrane. For Western blot analysis, the membranes were incubated for 60 min in Block solution containing 10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 150 mm NaCl, 10 mg/ml bovine serum albumin, 0.05% Tween 20. Membranes then were incubated in primary antibodies diluted in Block for another 60 min. Membrane was washed three times in Western rinse, incubated with horseradish peroxidase secondary antibody, washed, and developed with ECL (PerkinElmer Life Sciences). Finally, membranes were stripped by incubating them in a stripping buffer containing 6.25 mm Tris-HCl, pH 6.8, 2% SDS, and 100 mm β-mercaptoethanol at 50 °C for 30 min, washed in Western rinse, and reprobed with the antibody of interest. The Src kinase assay was performed as described previously (23Rahimi N. Hung W. Tremblay E. Saulnier R. Elliott B. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 33714-33721Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (143) Google Scholar). Briefly, lysates from PAE cells expressing wild type CKR or F1212/CKR were prepared, and equal protein amounts from each cell lysate were immunoprecipitated with anti-Src-2 antibody (Santa Cruz Biotechnology), which recognizes Src, Yes, and Fyn, and half of each immunoprecipitate was assayed for Src kinase activity by incubating with 10 μl of reaction buffer (20 mm PIPES, pH 7.0, 10 mm MnCl2, 10 μmNa3VO4), 5 μg of freshly prepared acid-denatured enolase (Sigma) min, and then 10 μCi of [γ-32P]ATP. After 10 min of incubation at 30 °C, reactions were terminated by the addition of 2× SDS sample buffer, and samples were subjected to SDS-PAGE. Serine and threonine phosphorylations were hydrolyzed by incubating the SDS-gel in 1m KOH at 45 °C for 30 min, followed by fixing in 45% methanol and 10% acetic acid for 30 min at room temperature, and dried at 80 °C under a vacuum and autoradiographed. Cell lysates from PAE cells expressing CKR and F1212/CKR were prepared, and equal protein amounts of each lysate were immunoprecipitated with anti-VEGFR-2 antibody as described above. Immunoprecipitates were washed twice with cold lysis buffer and once with cold kinase buffer (20 mm PIPES, pH 7.0, 10 mm MnCl2, 10 μmNa3VO4). In vitro VEGFR-2 kinase activity was determined by incubating immunoprecipitates with 20 μl of kinase buffer containing 10 μCi of [γ-32P]ATP at 30 °C for 20 min. The reaction was stopped by the addition of SDS sample buffer. Samples were boiled and subjected to SDS-PAGE. Serine and threonine phosphorylations were hydrolyzed by incubating the SDS-gel in 1 m KOH at 45 °C for 30 min, followed by fixing and drying as described above, and autoradiographed. VEGF provokes angiogenesis by engaging multiple endothelial cell surface receptors including VEGFR-1, VEGFR-2, and neuropilins (5Folkman J. D'Amore P Cell. 1996; 87: 1153-1155Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1096) Google Scholar, 6Carmeliet P. Jain R.K. Nature. 2000; 407: 249-257Crossref PubMed Scopus (7394) Google Scholar, 24Soker S. Takashima S. Miao H.Q. Neufeld G. Klagsbrun M. Cell. 1998; 92: 735-745Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2066) Google Scholar) by generating potentially homologous and heterologous signaling networks during angiogenesis. Since these receptors are very often expressed in the endothelial cells, it has been difficult to address the activation of specific signaling molecules by the individual receptors. We have recently constructed a chimeric receptor containing the extracellular domain of human CSF-1R/c-fms, fused with the transmembrane and the cytoplasmic domains of murine VEGFR-2 (8Rahimi N. Dayanir V. Lashkari K. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 16986-16992Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (197) Google Scholar). This model permitted us to dissect the function of VEGFR-2 in endothelial cells by selectively stimulating the receptor with CSF-1. Using the chimera system of VEGFR-2, we have shown that tyrosines 799 and 1173 are phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase binding sites and are required for endothelial cell proliferation (14Dayanir V. Meyer R.D. Lashkari K. Rahimi N. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 17686-17692Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar). In the current study, we have aimed to address the role of other tyrosine residues on VEGFR-2-mediated signal transduction. For this purpose, we have made additional mutations on mouse VEGFR-2 including tyrosines 820, 952, 997, 1212, and 1221. 2R. D. Meyer, V. Dayanir, F. Majnoun, and N. Rahimi, unpublished data. Our initial evaluation of the tyrosine mutant receptors showed that mutation of tyrosine 1212 unexpectedly impaired the ligand-dependent activation of VEGFR-2. This observation prompted us to characterize it further. In the current study, we have focused only on tyrosines 1173 and 1212. As illustrated in Fig.1A, tyrosines 1173 and 1212 are located at the C terminus of VEGFR-2. The tyrosine mutant receptors are named F1173/CKR and F1212/CKR, respectively, and are expressed in PAE cells. PAE cells expressing either an empty vector (pLNCX2), CKR, F1173/CKR, or F1212/CKR were lysed, and equal amounts of proteins were subjected to Western blot analysis by using an anti-VEGFR-2 antibody. As Fig. 1B shows, the wild type and the tyrosine mutant receptors are expressed at similar levels in PAE cells. As expected, cells expressing the empty vector, pLNCX2, were negative for receptor expression (Fig.1B). To analyze the role of tyrosine 1212 on the autophosphorylation of chimeric VEGFR-2 (CKR), we first compared the ability of F1212/CKR to become phosphorylated in response to CSF-1 with wild type CKR and F1173/CKR, which we have previously shown normally phosphorylated in response to CSF-1 stimulation (14Dayanir V. Meyer R.D. Lashkari K. Rahimi N. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 17686-17692Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar). PAE cells expressing these receptors were stimulated with CSF-1 (40 ng/ml) for 10 min, lysed, and immunoprecipitated using an anti-VEGFR-2 antibody. The immunoprecipitated proteins were subjected to Western blot analysis using an anti-phosphotyrosine antibody. Fig.2A shows that both wild type CKR and F11173/CKR were autophosphorylated in response to ligand stimulation. In contrast to wild type CKR and F1173/CKR, F1212/CKR was poorly autophosphorylated following CSF-1 stimulation under identical experimental conditions. Note that approximately equal amounts of receptor were present in each group (Fig. 2B). To test the ability of F1212/CKR to become autophosphorylated in vitro, the immunoprecipitated F1212/CKR was subjected to an in vitro kinase assay. Similarly, the autophosphorylation of F1212/CKR was greatly reduced, whereas a robust autophosphorylation of wild type receptor was evident (Fig. 2C). Next, we analyzed the kinetics of autophosphorylation of F1212/CKR. To this end, cells expressing CKR and F1212/CKR were stimulated with CSF-1 for different times, and kinetics of autophosphorylation of the two receptors were evaluated by immunoprecipitating the receptors with an anti-VEGFR-2 antibody and blotting them with anti-phosphotyrosine antibody. After 5 min of stimulation of cells expressing wild type CKR with CSF-1, a robust autophosphorylation of the receptor was observed and lasted up to 15 min. After 15 min of stimulation, the autophosphorylation of CKR gradually decreased (Fig. 2D). In contrast to enhanced ligand-dependent autophosphorylation of CKR, autophosphorylation of F1212/CKR was rather transient and was less intense. Its maximal autophosphorylation was observed after 5 min of CSF-1 stimulation, and after 30 min of stimulation no significant phosphorylation of receptor was observed (Fig. 2D). To determine whether an increase in concentration of CSF-1 overcomes the reduced autophosphorylation of F1212/CKR, cells expressing F1212/CKR were stimulated with increasing concentrations of CSF-1 ranging from 40–500 ng/ml. The result showed that stimulation with a higher concentration of ligand did not substantially improve F1212/CKR autophosphorylation (data not shown). To test whether mutation of tyrosine 1212 on VEGFR-2/FLK-1 (nonchimeric receptor) also impairs its ligand-dependent autophosphorylation, we also made F1212/VEGFR-2 and expressed it in PAE cells. The result, as demonstrated in Fig. 2F, shows that VEGF stimulation of PAE cells expressing wild type VEGFR-2 induces a robust tyrosine phosphorylation of wild type receptor but not of F1212/VEGFR-2. Altogether, information obtained from both chimeric and nonchimeric VEGFR-2 systems suggests that tyrosine 1212 plays a critical role in ligand-dependent activation of VEGFR-2. To elucidate the role of tyrosine 1212 in activation of signaling molecules, we evaluated activation of a number of signaling molecules including Src, PLCγ1, and MAPK. We initially tested the ability of F1212/CKR to associate with Src family kinases. To test this possibility, we tested the ability of GST-SH2-Src to bind CKR and F1212/CKR in an in vitro binding assay. To this end, cell lysates were incubated with GST-SH2-Src fusion protein linked to glutathione-Sepharose. The associated proteins were eluted, and the presence of CKR protein was detected by immunoblotting with anti-VEGFR-2 antibody. In the cell lysates of CSF-1-stimulated cells expressing CKR, GST-SH2 Src protein formed stable complexes with CKR protein. However, cell lysates of CSF-1-stimulated cells expressing F1212/CKR incubated with GST-SH2 Src protein were negative for F1212/CKR protein (Fig. 3A). To assess Src activation, cells expressing wild type CKR and F1212/CKR were stimulated for 10 and 30 min, and Src family proteins (Src, Fyn and Yes) were immunoprecipitated with a pan anti-Src antibody that recognizes Src, Fyn, and Yes. The immunoprecipitated proteins were either subjected to Western blot analysis using a phosphospecific Src antibody or subjected to an in vitro Src kinase assay using acid-denatured enolase as a substrate. As Fig. 3 (B andD) shows, stimulation of cells expressing wild type CKR with CSF-1 resulted in activation of Src in a time-dependent manner. In contrast to wild type CKR, stimulation of F1212/CKR failed to significantly activate Src in both in vitro kinase assay and Western blot analysis using an anti-phospho-Src antibody. To examine the ability of F1212/CKR to activate other signaling proteins, we also examined activation of PLCγ and MAPK. To this end, cells were stimulated with CSF-1 for 10 min and evaluated by subjecting total cell lysates to Western blot analysis by using phosphospecific antibodies that recognize the active form PLCγ and MAPK, respectively. As illustrated in Fig. 4(A and C), stimulation of cells expressing CKR and F1173/CKR resulted in significant activation of PLC1γ and MAPK. However, stimulation of PLCγ1 and MAPK by F1212/CKR was greatly reduced. In addition, F1212/CKR failed to stimulate SHC phosphorylation (data not shown). In human VEGFR-2, tyrosine 1175 (corresponding to 1173 on mouse VEGFR-2) is reported to be responsible for PLCγ1 activation (11Takahashi T. Yamaguchi S. Chida K. Shibuya M. EMBO J. 2001; 20: 2768-2778Crossref PubMed Scopus (599) Google Scholar). However, as we previously reported (Ref. 14Dayanir V. Meyer R.D. Lashkari K. Rahimi N. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 17686-17692Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar and data presented here), in this system, mutation of tyrosine 1173 to phenylalanine causes no measurable effect on PLCγ1 activation. Collectively, these data suggest that mutation of tyrosine 1212 to phenylalanine abolishes the ability of VEGFR-2 to activate a number of signaling proteins, including Src, PLCγ1, and MAPK. Since mutation of tyrosine 1212 of VEGFR-2 to phenylalanine impairs the ligand-dependent autophosphorylation of receptor, it is difficult to analyze the role of tyrosine 1212 on VEGFR-2-mediated signal transduction relay. To overcome this problem, we have replaced tyrosine 1212 with glutamic acid. This type of mutation has been suggested to be a useful approach for characterization of sensitive tyrosine sites on the receptor tyrosine kinases when their mutation to phenylalanine interferes with receptor activation (27Zisch A.H. Pazzagli C. Freeman A.L. Schneller M. Hadman M. Smith J.W. Ruoslahti E. Pasquale E.B. Oncogene. 2000; 19: 177-187Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar). To test whether replacement of tyrosine 1212 with glutamic acid can rescue and preserve the ligand-dependent activation of VEGFR-2, we mutated tyrosine 1212 to phenylalanine and expressed it in a similar manner in PAE cells. As demonstrated in Fig.5A, E1212/CKR, unlike F1212/CKR, is fully autophosphorylated following stimulation of PAE cells expressing E1212/CKR, whereas F1212/CKR failed to undergo ligand-dependent autophosphorylation both in vivo and in vitro (Fig. 5, A andC). To test whether E1212/CKR is also able to activate signaling proteins, we initially evaluated the ability of this receptor to activate Src. As demonstrated in Fig. 5D, E1212/CKR was able to activate Src significantly in a ligand- and time-dependent manner. Indeed, it also appears that E1212/CKR was able to activate Src slightly better than wild type receptor, as is evident by its ability to activate Src (Fig.5D). To test the ability of E1212/CKR to associate with Src, we subjected cell lysates obtained from cells expressing E1212/CKR to an in vitro binding assay using GST-SH2-Src fusion protein. Fig. 5F shows that wild type receptor and E1212/CKR but not F1212 can associate with Src following stimulation of cells with ligand. Collectively, these results suggest that tyrosine 1212 is not involved in association with Src and its activation. We also evaluated the ability of E1212/CKR to activate other signaling proteins, including PLCγ and MAPK. As demonstrated in Fig.6A, E1212/CKR, like wild type receptor, was able to activate PLCγ in a time-dependent manner. Similarly, E1212/CKR was able to activate MAPK in manner similar to CKR stimulation (Fig. 6C).Figure 6Replacement of tyrosine 1212 with glutamic acid (E) preserves the VEGFR-2-dependent activation of PLC γ and MAPK. The same membranes were reprobed with anti- PLCγ1 antibody and anti-MAPK antibody, respectively (B and D).View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) Recently, it has been suggested that activation of Src may play a critical role in autophosphorylation of some receptor tyrosine kinases, including the EGF receptor, CSF-1 receptor, and PDGFR (15Reith A.D. Ellis C. Maroc N. Pawson T. Bernstein A. Dubreuil P. Oncogene. 1993; 8: 45-53PubMed Google Scholar, 16Ataliotis P. Symes K. Chou M.M., Ho, L. Mercola M. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 2257-2264Crossref PubMed Scopus (295) Google Scholar, 18Zisch A.H. Kalo M.S. Chong L.D. Pasquale E.B. Oncogene. 1998; 16: 2657-2670Crossref PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar, 19Baxter R.M. Secrist J.P. Vaillancourt R.R. Kazlauskas A. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 17050-17055Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar). To test whether Src activation is required for full autophosphorylation of VEGFR-2, we initially co-expressed wild type Src and kinase-dead Src (Src/KD) in PAE cells. Fig.7A illustrates overexpression of wild type Src or kinase-dead Src (Src/KD) in PAE cells expressing CKR. Overexpression of kinase-dead Src significantly reduced the Src activity in PAE cells; conversely, overexpression of wild-type Src increased Src kinase activation (data not shown). To analyze the effect of overexpression of Src and Src/KD in CKR autophosphorylation, we first stimulated these cells with CSF-1 and evaluated its tyrosine phosphorylation by Western blot analysis using an anti-phosphotyrosine antibody. Fig. 7B shows that overexpression of Src is not required for overall tyrosine phosphorylation of CKR. To test the role of Src in CKR tyrosine phosphorylation in a more convincing manner, we expressed CKR in a triple knockout (Src, Yes, Fyn) fibroblast cells, SYF. The data showed that stimulation of CKR expressed in SYF cells results in a ligand-dependent tyrosine phosphorylation in a similar manner to that of CKR stimulated in PAE cells (Fig.7D). Collectively, the data suggest that Src family kinases are not required for full activation of CKR, and furthermore, the data indicate that the reduced tyrosine phosphorylation of F1212/CKR is not associated with Src activity in target cells. Activation of VEGFR-2 is considered to be an essential requirement for vasculogenesis and angiogenesis, which is associated with many human pathological disorders ranging from cancer to diabetes (3Kim K.J., Li, B. Winer J. Armanini M. Gillett N. Phillips H.S. Ferrara N. Nature. 1993; 362: 841-844Crossref PubMed Scopus (3337) Google Scholar, 4Risau W. Nature. 1997; 386: 671-674Crossref PubMed Scopus (4805) Google Scholar, 5Folkman J. D'Amore P Cell. 1996; 87: 1153-1155Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1096) Google Scholar). However, the molecular mechanism of activation of VEGFR-2 is largely unknown. In the current study, we have examined the requirement of tyrosine 1212 for VEGFR-2 functions. Our results indicate that the presence of tyrosine 1212 is essential for the ligand-dependent autophosphorylation of VEGFR-2 and its association with signaling proteins in endothelial cells. Replacement of tyrosine 1212 with phenylalanine on chimeric VEGFR-2 severely impaired its autophosphorylation in response to ligand stimulation bothin vivo and in vitro. The effect of mutation of tyrosine 1212 on autophosphorylation of VEGFR-2 was surprising, since mutation of other tyrosines including 799, 820, 952, 997, 1173, and 1221 did not alter the ligand-dependent autophosphorylation of VEGFR-2 (14Dayanir V. Meyer R.D. Lashkari K. Rahimi N. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 17686-17692Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar).2 These findings demonstrate that the ligand-dependent activation of VEGFR-2 in part requires the presence of tyrosine 1212 for its full activation. In addition to impairment in the autophosphorylation of VEGFR-2, mutation of tyrosine 1212 also caused the receptor not to associate with and activate Src kinases. Tyrosine phosphorylation of other signaling molecules including PLCγ1 and MAPK were also greatly affected. How does tyrosine 1212 influence the kinase activation of VEGFR-2? Initial biochemical analysis of other growth receptors such as PDGFR-β, EGFR, c-kit, c-fms, and Eph suggested that mutation of one or two tyrosine residues at the juxtamembrane domain to phenylalanine interferes with the receptor's kinase activation. The tyrosine mutant receptors at the juxtamembrane domain also failed to activate Src family kinases (15Reith A.D. Ellis C. Maroc N. Pawson T. Bernstein A. Dubreuil P. Oncogene. 1993; 8: 45-53PubMed Google Scholar, 16Ataliotis P. Symes K. Chou M.M., Ho, L. Mercola M. Development. 1995; 121: 3099-3110PubMed Google Scholar, 17Mori S. Ronnstrand L. Yokote K. Engstrom A. Courtneidge S.A. Claesson-Welsh L. Heldin C.H. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 2257-2264Crossref PubMed Scopus (295) Google Scholar, 18Zisch A.H. Kalo M.S. Chong L.D. Pasquale E.B. Oncogene. 1998; 16: 2657-2670Crossref PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar, 19Baxter R.M. Secrist J.P. Vaillancourt R.R. Kazlauskas A. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 17050-17055Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar). Based on this correlation, it has been suggested that Src family kinases in part might be responsible for full activation of receptor tyrosine kinases (15Reith A.D. Ellis C. Maroc N. Pawson T. Bernstein A. Dubreuil P. Oncogene. 1993; 8: 45-53PubMed Google Scholar, 16Ataliotis P. Symes K. Chou M.M., Ho, L. Mercola M. Development. 1995; 121: 3099-3110PubMed Google Scholar, 17Mori S. Ronnstrand L. Yokote K. Engstrom A. Courtneidge S.A. Claesson-Welsh L. Heldin C.H. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 2257-2264Crossref PubMed Scopus (295) Google Scholar, 18Zisch A.H. Kalo M.S. Chong L.D. Pasquale E.B. Oncogene. 1998; 16: 2657-2670Crossref PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar, 19Baxter R.M. Secrist J.P. Vaillancourt R.R. Kazlauskas A. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 17050-17055Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar). However, a recent finding demonstrating that PDGFR-β is fully functional and autophosphorylated in triple knockout Src (SYF) cells undermines the previous conclusion (20Klinghoffer R.A. Sachsenmaier C. Cooper J.A. Soriano P. EMBO J. 1999; 18: 2459-2471Crossref PubMed Scopus (646) Google Scholar). In agreement with this finding, our study demonstrates that ligand-dependent autophosphorylation of VEGFR-2 in Src-deficient cells (SYF) is not impaired, suggesting that Src kinases are not engaged in the ligand-dependent activation of VEGFR-2. The role of tyrosine residues located outside the kinase domain of receptor tyrosine kinases in general and the role of phosphorylation of tyrosine 1212 in VEGFR-2 activation in particular are not clear. One possible explanation is that certain tyrosine residues located outside the catalytic domain of receptor tyrosine kinases play a dual function by both functioning as a docking site for SH2-containing cytoplasmic signaling proteins and participating in autoinhibition of receptor tyrosine kinases. The idea that juxtamembrane and carboxyl domains are involved in autoinhibition of kinase activity of receptor tyrosine kinases is supported by the recent crystal structure of TIE2/Tek and EphB2. For instance, in the unstimulated state, the carboxyl domain of TIE2 occupies its substrate binding sites; however, autophosphorylation of tyrosine sites in the carboxyl domain of TIE2 exposes its phosphotyrosine residues for substrate binding and kinase activation. The juxtamembrane domain of EphB2 may play a similar role in suppression of kinase activation of EphB2 receptor. The phosphorylation at the tyrosine residue appears to relive the repression of receptor by causing dissociation of the juxtamembrane domain from the kinase region (27Zisch A.H. Pazzagli C. Freeman A.L. Schneller M. Hadman M. Smith J.W. Ruoslahti E. Pasquale E.B. Oncogene. 2000; 19: 177-187Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar). Consistent with the above findings, the recent study on the EphB2 receptor also suggests a possible regulatory role for tyrosine phosphorylation sites located outside the kinase domain. Replacement of tyrosine 605 and 611 with phenylalanine on the EphB2 receptor abolishes its kinase activation and its ability to associate with signaling proteins. Remarkably, replacement of the same tyrosine sites with glutamic acid preserves the EphB2 kinase activation (27Zisch A.H. Pazzagli C. Freeman A.L. Schneller M. Hadman M. Smith J.W. Ruoslahti E. Pasquale E.B. Oncogene. 2000; 19: 177-187Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar). Our demonstration that the replacement of tyrosine 1212 on VEGFR-2 with glutamic acid also maintains the ligand-dependent autophosphorylation of VEGFR-2 for possible involvement of this tyrosine residue in the autoregulation of kinase activation of VEGFR-2. A recent study by Takahashi et al. (11Takahashi T. Yamaguchi S. Chida K. Shibuya M. EMBO J. 2001; 20: 2768-2778Crossref PubMed Scopus (599) Google Scholar) shows that tyrosine 1214 in human VEGFR-2 (corresponding to tyrosine 1212 in mouse VEGFR-2) also is autophosphorylated in vivo (11Takahashi T. Yamaguchi S. Chida K. Shibuya M. EMBO J. 2001; 20: 2768-2778Crossref PubMed Scopus (599) Google Scholar). However, in contrast to what we observed with murine VEGFR-2, they found that replacement of tyrosine 1214 in the human VEGFR-2 with phenylalanine did not affect PLCγ1 activation, whereas mutation of 1175 (corresponding to tyrosine 1173 on mouse VEGFR-2) did (11Takahashi T. Yamaguchi S. Chida K. Shibuya M. EMBO J. 2001; 20: 2768-2778Crossref PubMed Scopus (599) Google Scholar). The reason for this apparent discrepancy is not clear; however, this could reflect some unanticipated differences between the human and murine VEGFR-2. Alternatively, it could be a reflection of differences between the cell lines used in the two analyses. The mechanism by which PLCγ1 is activated by VEGFR-2 remains elusive, since other tyrosine sites such as 799 and 952 were also reported to be responsible for activation of PLCγ1 (32Cunningham S.A. Arrate M.P. Brock T.A. Waxham M.N. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1997; 240: 635-639Crossref PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar, 33Wu L.W. Mayo L.D. Dunbar J.D. Kessler K.M. Ozes O.N. Warren R.S. Donner D.B. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 6059-6062Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (95) Google Scholar). Thus, it appears that the primary contribution of tyrosine phosphorylation of 1212 is to regulate the kinase activation of VEGFR-2, whereas autophosphorylation of other tyrosine sites such as 799, 1173, and 957 function for mediating interactions with signaling proteins (11Takahashi T. Yamaguchi S. Chida K. Shibuya M. EMBO J. 2001; 20: 2768-2778Crossref PubMed Scopus (599) Google Scholar, 14Dayanir V. Meyer R.D. Lashkari K. Rahimi N. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 17686-17692Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar). Further studies will reveal how tyrosine 1212 of VEGFR-2 contributes to ligand-dependent activation of VEGFR-2 and whether this tyrosine residue also associates with SH2-containing signaling proteins. In conclusion, we have identified tyrosine 1212 of VEGFR-2 responsible for ligand-dependent activation of VEGFR-2 and its associated signaling proteins. Regulation of angiogenesis is considered to be a promising approach for treatment of many human diseases associated with uncontrolled angiogenesis. This study suggests that targeting the tyrosine 1212 of VEGFR-2 may provide effective therapeutic interventions aimed to curb angiogenesis. We thank Dr. M. Nugent and Rick Singh for reading and commenting on the manuscript.

The heme polymer hemozoin is produced in the food vacuole (fv) of the parasite after hemoglobin proteolysis and is the target of the drug chloroquine. A candidate heme polymerase, the histidine-rich protein II (HRPII), is proposed to be delivered to the fv by ingestion of the infected-red cell cytoplasm. Here we show that 97% of endogenous Plasmodium falciparum (Pf) HRPII (PfHRPII) is secreted as soluble protein in the periphery of the red cell and avoids endocytosis by the parasite, and 3% remains membrane-bound within the parasite. Transfected cells release 90% of a soluble transgene PfHRPIImyc into the red cell periphery and contain 10% membrane bound within the parasite. Yet these cells show a minor reduction in hemozoin production and IC50 for chloroquine. They also show decreased transport of resident fv enzyme PfPlasmepsin I, the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) marker PfBiP, and parasite-associated HRPII to fvs. Instead, all three proteins accumulate in the ER, although there is no defect in protein export from the parasite. The data suggest that novel mechanisms of sorting (i) soluble antigens like HRPII in the red cell cytoplasm and (ii) fv-bound membrane complexes in the ER regulate parasite digestive processes. The heme polymer hemozoin is produced in the food vacuole (fv) of the parasite after hemoglobin proteolysis and is the target of the drug chloroquine. A candidate heme polymerase, the histidine-rich protein II (HRPII), is proposed to be delivered to the fv by ingestion of the infected-red cell cytoplasm. Here we show that 97% of endogenous Plasmodium falciparum (Pf) HRPII (PfHRPII) is secreted as soluble protein in the periphery of the red cell and avoids endocytosis by the parasite, and 3% remains membrane-bound within the parasite. Transfected cells release 90% of a soluble transgene PfHRPIImyc into the red cell periphery and contain 10% membrane bound within the parasite. Yet these cells show a minor reduction in hemozoin production and IC50 for chloroquine. They also show decreased transport of resident fv enzyme PfPlasmepsin I, the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) marker PfBiP, and parasite-associated HRPII to fvs. Instead, all three proteins accumulate in the ER, although there is no defect in protein export from the parasite. The data suggest that novel mechanisms of sorting (i) soluble antigens like HRPII in the red cell cytoplasm and (ii) fv-bound membrane complexes in the ER regulate parasite digestive processes. parasitophorous vacuolar membrane food vacuole histidine-rich protein II P. falciparum HRPII endoplasmic reticulum fluorescein isothiocyanate phosphate-buffered saline brefeldin A acyl carrier protein-green fluorescent protein field emission in-lens scanning electron microscopy luminal binding protein Plasmodium falciparum is a protozoan parasite that causes the most virulent of human malarias (1Walsh J.A. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 1989; 569: 1-16Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar, 2Holder A.A. Hoffman S.L. Mararia Vaccine Development: A Multi-immune Response and Multi-stage Perspective. American Society for Microbiology, Washington, D. C.1996: 77-104Google Scholar). During the blood stages of infection, it invades and develops within a parasitophorous vacuolar membrane (PVM)1 in a red cell (3Gratzer W.B. Dluzewski A.R. Semin. Hematol. 1993; 30: 232-247PubMed Google Scholar). The parasite exports numerous proteins to the cytoplasm and membrane of the red cell (4Deitsch K.W. Wellems T.E. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1996; 76: 1-10Crossref PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar). Association with the host skeleton or insertion across its membrane is thought to be required to keep the protein in the periphery of the red cell. Soluble exported proteins are expected to be ingested with hemoglobin and delivered to the fv within the parasite (3Gratzer W.B. Dluzewski A.R. Semin. Hematol. 1993; 30: 232-247PubMed Google Scholar, 5Goldberg D.E. Semin. Cell Biol. 1993; 4: 355-361Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar). The parasite ingests and degrades ∼80% of the hemoglobin in the red cell (3Gratzer W.B. Dluzewski A.R. Semin. Hematol. 1993; 30: 232-247PubMed Google Scholar, 5Goldberg D.E. Semin. Cell Biol. 1993; 4: 355-361Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar). Ingestion occurs via a specialized organelle called the cytostome, which is a double membrane invagination of the parasite plasma membrane (PPM) and PVM (see Fig. 1). The cytostome pinches off to form a large, double membrane vesicle containing hemoglobin that fuses with the fv where hemoglobin is degraded (Fig. 1). The released, toxic-free heme is detoxified by polymerization to hemozoin (6Fitch C.D. Kanjananggulpan P. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 15552-15555Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 7Slater A.F. Swiggard W.J. Orton B.R. Flitter W.D. Goldberg D.E. Cerami A. Henderson G.B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 325-329Crossref PubMed Scopus (483) Google Scholar). Heme polymerization is also likely to be the main target of chloroquine, of which the emergence of drug resistance is a major problem in controlling malaria (8Moran J.S. Bernard K.W. J. Am. Med. Assoc. 1989; 262: 245-248Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar, 9World Health OrganizationTrans. R. Soc. Trop. Med. Hyg. 1990; 84 Suppl. 2: 1-65Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1020) Google Scholar, 10World Health Organization, Division of Control of Tropical DiseasesAssessment of Therapeutic Efficacy of Antimalarial Drugs for Uncomplicated Falciparum Malaria in Areas of Intense Transmission, WHO/MAL/96.1077. World Health Organization, Geneva1996Google Scholar). Histidine-rich proteins have been shown to function as heme polymerasesin vitro, and the best characterized of these proteins isP. falciparum HRPII (or PfHRPII) (11Sullivan Jr., D.J. Gluzman I.Y. Goldberg D.E. Science. 1996; 271: 219-222Crossref PubMed Scopus (353) Google Scholar, 12Tyas L. Gluzman I. Moon R.P. Rupp K. Westling J. Ridley R.G. Kay J. Goldberg D.E. Berry C. FEBS Lett. 1999; 454: 210-214Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar, 13Papalexis V. Siomos M.A. Campanale N. Guo X. Kocak G. Foley M. Tilley L. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 2001; 115: 77-86Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar). This protein has been detected in the red cell as well as the fv, leading to the suggestion that it is ingested from the red cell by the cytostome along with hemoglobin and subsequently delivered to the fv. Early studies also suggest that resident fv proteases synthesized in a membrane-bound pro-form are transported to the PVM and then retrieved into the newly developing cytostome, which ingests hemoglobin (11Sullivan Jr., D.J. Gluzman I.Y. Goldberg D.E. Science. 1996; 271: 219-222Crossref PubMed Scopus (353) Google Scholar, 14Francis S.E. Gluzman I.Y. Oksman A. Knickerbocker A. Mueller R. Bryant M.L. Sherman D.R. Russell D.G. Goldberg D.E. EMBO J. 1994; 13: 306-317Crossref PubMed Scopus (251) Google Scholar). This has rendered attractive a general model that both membrane and lumenal components of food vacuole may be delivered to the PV and the red cell from where they are internalized into the fv (5Goldberg D.E. Semin. Cell Biol. 1993; 4: 355-361Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar). This is because (as indicated earlier) soluble proteins in the red cell cytoplasm are not expected to be segregated. Yet whether cytosolic antigens in the red cell can avoid ingestion has never been evaluated. In mammalian cells and yeast, lumenal, resident proteases are thought to be exported from the ER and sorted in the Golgi for transport to the lysosomes and fv, respectively (15Bryant N.J. Stevens T.H. Microbiol. Mol. Biol. Rev. 1998; 62: 230-247Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 16Mullins C. Bonifacino J.S. Bioessays. 2001; 23: 333-343Crossref PubMed Scopus (168) Google Scholar), but to what extent this model serves in lower eukaryotic pathogens like the malaria parasite is not known. The function of HRPII in heme polymerization has been difficult to evaluate in intact, infected red cells. Although the heme polymerase activity (which is ascribed to the histidine-rich sequences of this protein and other histidine-rich proteins and peptides) has been demonstrated in vitro (11Sullivan Jr., D.J. Gluzman I.Y. Goldberg D.E. Science. 1996; 271: 219-222Crossref PubMed Scopus (353) Google Scholar, 13Papalexis V. Siomos M.A. Campanale N. Guo X. Kocak G. Foley M. Tilley L. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 2001; 115: 77-86Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar), a laboratory cell line with a natural deletion in HRPII and HRPIII can still produce hemozoin (11Sullivan Jr., D.J. Gluzman I.Y. Goldberg D.E. Science. 1996; 271: 219-222Crossref PubMed Scopus (353) Google Scholar). Thus, additional histidine-rich proteins may contribute to hemozoin production. Our understanding has been further limited by the fact that although there is evidence that PfHRPII is delivered to the infected red cell cytosol and the fv as well as the extracellular medium, a detailed characterization quantitating the distribution of the protein and its transport properties has not been undertaken. Analysis of the primary structure of HRPII using Signal P suggests an N-terminal signal sequence and predicted cleavage site. However, the values for both are low, and this raises further questions of whether the protein is efficiently recruited into the ER-Golgi secretory pathway in its transport to diverse cellular destinations. In this study, we have transfected P. falciparum-infected red cells to express PfHRPII tagged with a C-terminal c-Myc epitope under continuous selection. Using high resolution microscopy and biochemical cell fractionation assays, we have characterized the distribution of the native protein and its Myc-tagged counterpart in the parasite and the red cell to understand their functional consequences. The specific questions we asked were the following. (i) Are PfHRPII and PfHRPIImyc exported to the red cell and subsequently endocytosed into the parasite or released across the red cell membrane? (ii) Are PfHRPII and PfHRPIImyc detected within the parasite and the fv? (iii) Are these proteins recruited into the secretory pathway, and do cells expressing HRPIImyc show perturbations in secretory organization, protein export to the red cell and/or the fv? (v) Do the transformed cells show changes in heme polymerization and/or sensitivity to chloroquine? To examine stage-specific events (from 6 to 42 h), parasites were synchronized to 4 h of growth using a combination of Percoll purification and sorbitol treatments, cultured to 10% parasitemia, and harvested at the indicated times. Parasite growth was measured by examining Giemsa-stained blood smears and hypoxanthine incorporation (20Akompong T. VanWye J. Ghori N. Haldar K. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1999; 101: 71-79Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar) into parasite DNA. Cell counts were determined using a hematocytometer. The plasmid pHCHRP2m was constructed as follows. HRP II open reading frame was PCR-amplified by using primers GCTCGAGATGGTTTCCTTCTCAAAAAATAAAGTATTATCCG and GCAAGCTTAATGGCGTAGGCAATGTGTGGCGGC from P. falciparumFCB total DNA, restricted with BamHI, and cloned intoSmaI-BglII-restricted pBSExp-1 to introduce c-Myc epitope sequence at the 3′ end. The insert was sequenced and then recovered by XhoI digestion to clone into the plasmid pHC1 (a gift from Dr. Alan Cowman, Melbourne, Australia) to obtain pHCHRP2m. The construction of the ACPGFP line has previously been described (21Kadekoppala M. Cheresh P. Catron D. Ji D.D. Deitsch K. Wellems T.E. Seifert H.S. Haldar K. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 2001; 112: 211-218Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar). Ring-infected red cells at a parasitemia of 10% were transfected with Qiagen-purified supercoiled plasmid DNA by electroporation as described by Fidock et al. (22Fidock D.A. Nomura T. Wellems T.E. Mol. Pharmacol. 1998; 54: 1140-1147Crossref PubMed Scopus (142) Google Scholar) using Bio-Rad Gene pulser II with settings of 0.31 KV and 950 microfarads. Forty-eight h after transfection, pyrimethamine (Sigma) was added to the culture media and maintained at a concentration of 100 ng/ml for 2 days. The concentration of drug was subsequently reduced to 25 ng/ml and maintained at 25 ng/ml. Parasites were cloned by serial dilution to isolate pyrimethamine-resistant HRPII expressing P. falciparum E8 clone. Infected red cells were attached to poly-l-lysine-coated cover slips (20Akompong T. VanWye J. Ghori N. Haldar K. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1999; 101: 71-79Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). Where indicated, the cells were permeabilized in 0.01% saponin to release red cell contents. Intact or permeabilized cells were subsequently fixed with 1% paraformaldehyde for 10 min and permeabilized with 0.05% saponin for 20 min. The cells were incubated with 0.2% gelatin for 30 min followed by incubation with primary antibodies and secondary antibodies (diluted with PBS containing 0.01% saponin). Isolated fvs were allowed to air dry and then were permeabilized with saponin and probed with primary and secondary antibodies. Epifluorescence images (30 optical sections of 0.2-mm thickness) were collected by DeltaVision microscopy with a 100× oil objective (1.35 NA) attached to a cooled charge-coupled device (CCD) camera. A series of single optical sections were obtained, and the images were deconvolved on a SGI work station by using SoftWoRx Version 2.5. Saponin permeabilization was carried out by mixing infected erythrocytes with 10 volumes of 0.01% saponin followed by incubating at 4 °C for 10 min (this selectively lyses erythrocyte membrane, tubovesicular membrane (TVN), PVM but is expected to leave intact the parasite plasma membrane). The saponin lysates were subjected to centrifugation at 2,200 × g for 10 min, and the supernatant (enriched in the erythrocyte cytosolic content) was collected. The pellet containing isolated parasites was washed three times with cold PBS. Supernatant and pellet fractions were assayed for glutamate dehydrogenase activity (by measuring the change inA 340 as a result of the conversion of NADPH to NADP+ as described by Vander Jagt et al. (23Vander Jagt D.L. Intress C. Heidrich J.E. Mrema J.E. Rieckmann K.H. Heidrich H.G. J. Parasitol. 1982; 68: 1068-1071Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar)) to determine whether the parasite plasma membrane had ruptured or parasites contaminated the supernatant fraction. Hypotonic lysates were prepared by mixing infected cells with 10 volumes of water followed by vigorous vortexing in the presence of protease inhibitors. The lysate was subjected to centrifugation at 100,000 × g, the supernatant and pellet fractions were collected. The samples obtained after saponin treatment or hypotonic lysis were solubilized in 5 volumes of 1× SDS-PAGE sample buffer, boiled for 3–5 min, separated by SDS-PAGE, and transferred to nitrocellulose filters. The filters were incubated with 5% nonfat dry milk for 30 min and subsequently incubated with either anti-HRPII antibody (1:1000) or anti-C-myc antibody (1:500) for 1 h at room temperature. They were then washed with Tris-buffered saline containing 0.05% Tween 20 and incubated with peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibody (1:2000) for 1 h at room temperature. The bands were developed with ECL solutions as per the manufacturer's protocol. To release hemozoin from parasites, infected cells were first lysed with 0.01% saponin for 10 min at room temperature to release parasites from red cell ghosts. The parasites were washed 3 times with PBS, resuspended in 2.5% SDS in PBS, and subjected to centrifugation at 20,000 ×g for 1 h. The supernatant was discarded, and the insoluble pellet was washed again in 2.5% SDS in PBS and then dissolved in 20 mm NaOH. The hemozoin content was measured by determining the absorbance at 400 nm and using a standard curve generated with hematin. Food vacuoles were isolated by the method of Goldberg et al. (31Goldberg D.E. Slater A.F. Cerami A. Henderson G.B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 2931-2935Crossref PubMed Scopus (400) Google Scholar). Briefly, cells were harvested by centrifugation, washed 3× with PBS, resuspended in 5 volumes of 5% sorbitol, and incubated at room temperature for 20 min. The lysate was centrifuged at 600 × g for 7 min. The resulting supernatant was centrifuged at 2200 × g for 10 min and the pellet was treated with saponin and processed as described by Goldberg et al. (31Goldberg D.E. Slater A.F. Cerami A. Henderson G.B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 2931-2935Crossref PubMed Scopus (400) Google Scholar). The resulting lysate was layered on top of a Percoll gradient. Isolated vacuoles were collected from the bottom fraction. The fv enzyme plasmepsin I was used as a marker for purification. Isolated fv fraction showed 10-fold enrichment with a yield of 30%. Red cells (1 × 109) infected with either 3D7 or E8 (15–20% parasitemia) were washed twice with methionine-free RPMI and incubated in 10 ml of PBS containing 4.5 mg/ml glucose and 500 μCi of [35S]methionine-[35S]cysteine at 37 °C for 2 h. The cells were collected by centrifugation and washed 3 times with PBS at 4 °C. The cells were lysed with 0.01% saponin at room temperature for 10 min and subject to centrifugation at 2200 × g for 10 min. The supernatant (red cell cytosol) was saved and processed for SDS-PAGE. The gel was dried and exposed to film to analyze the pattern of exported proteins in the different lines. 1–2 × 108 cells from E8 or 3D7 cultures were washed in PBS and fixed in 1% formaldehyde in PBS for 15 min. Excess aldehyde was removed, and the cells were incubated with anti-HRPII antibody for 30 min followed by FITC-conjugated secondary antibody for 30 min. The parasite nuclei were stained with propidium iodide (10 μl/ml). Where indicated, after fixation the cells were permeabilized by treatment with 0.05% saponin for 20 min and subsequently processed for antibody binding. Samples were analyzed on a BD PharMingen FACScan (FACSCALIBUR). Data was analyzed with CELLQuest software, and fluorescence histograms and dot plots were displayed on a four-decade logarithmic scale. E8-infected red cells were fixed in a mixture of 2% glutaraldehyde, 1% tannic acid, and 4% sucrose in a 0.05 m phosphate buffer, pH 7.4, for 2 h and post-fixed in 1% osmium tetraoxide for 1 h. Samples were then block-stained in 0.5% aqueous uranyl acetate, dehydrated in ascending concentrations of ethanol, and embedded in Epon 812. Ultrathin sections were stained with 2% uranyl acetate in 50% methanol and lead citrate and examined in a Zeiss CEM902 electron microscope (Oberkochen, Germany). Samples were prepared for FEISEM as described by Chenet al. (25Chen M.M. Shi L. Sullivan Jr., D.J. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 2001; 113: 1-8Crossref PubMed Scopus (109) Google Scholar). Before sample application, 5 × 5-mm silica chips (Ted Pella, catalog #16008) were cleaned with ethanol, coated with polylysine, and then rinsed three times with distilled water. One-three nmol of heme polymer were applied onto chips in distilled water. After centrifugation at 3000 × g for 10 min, heme crystals formed a thin layer on chip surfaces. Chips were then stained with 2% uranyl acetate for 30–60 min. After one quick rinse with 50% ethanol, chips were rinsed consecutively in 50, 70, and 90% ethanol for 3 min each. After critical point drying for 1–2 h, chips were coated with chromium. Silica chips loaded with samples were ready for field emission in-lens scanning electron microscopy (LEO 1550) Plasmodium infection of red cells begins with the intracellular “ring” stage that lasts for the next 24 h. The parasite then matures through a second, morphologically distinct trophozoite stage (24–36 h) to enter the terminal stages of schizogony, where mitosis occurs and daughter merozoites assemble (36–48 h). At the end of schizogony, the infected red cells lyse to release merozoites (into the extracellular medium) that re-invade erythrocytes and thereby maintain the asexual cycle (Fig.1). As previously shown (11Sullivan Jr., D.J. Gluzman I.Y. Goldberg D.E. Science. 1996; 271: 219-222Crossref PubMed Scopus (353) Google Scholar, 13Papalexis V. Siomos M.A. Campanale N. Guo X. Kocak G. Foley M. Tilley L. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 2001; 115: 77-86Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar, 26Howard R.J. Shigehiko U. Aikawa M. Aley S.B. Leech J.H. Lew A.M. Wellems T.E. Rener J. Taylor D.W. J. Cell Biol. 1986; 103: 1269-1277Crossref PubMed Scopus (251) Google Scholar), endogenous PfHRPII is detected in the infected erythrocyte cytoplasm of ring and schizont stages (Fig.2 A). Western blots also indicate that the protein is expressed in 12-h ring stage parasites and largely maintained through the trophozoite stage and in schizonts (Fig.2 B); however, northern blots show that HRPII RNA is present only in ring stages (Fig. 2 C). This suggests that after 24 h, trophozoites and schizonts do not synthesize PfHRPIIde novo, and most of the protein made in rings remains associated with these later stage parasites and are not transported to the extracellular medium. To examine what fraction of the total, cell-associated PfHRPII protein is exported from the parasite, we lysed synchronized, trophozoite-infected red cells (30–33 h; which express maximal levels of HRPII) with 0.01% saponin (Fig. 2 D, i). As shown, 97% was found in the supernatant fraction. This treatment does not release the parasite cytosolic enzyme glutamate dehydrogenase (Fig.2 D, ii), confirming that the parasite plasma membrane is intact and is consistent with previous studies that saponin selectively perforates the red cell membrane and the PVM but not the parasite plasma membrane (23Vander Jagt D.L. Intress C. Heidrich J.E. Mrema J.E. Rieckmann K.H. Heidrich H.G. J. Parasitol. 1982; 68: 1068-1071Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar, 27Crary J.L. Haldar K. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1992; 53: 185-192Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar). The secretory marker PfBiP is also not released, as expected if the parasite plasma membrane is intact (Fig. 2 D, iii). Together these data show that by the trophozoite stage (30–33 h) the vast majority of HRPII is exported from the parasite to the red cell. A time course of export from the parasite shown in Fig. 2 E,i, indicates that most of the export is achieved by the late ring (24 h) stage. 90% of this exported protein can be detected at schizogony (>36 h). The experimental error (due to variation in cell counts and low levels of cell loss at schizogony) is 10%, suggesting that the levels of exported protein essentially do not change after 24 h of development. That there is no new synthesis of protein after 24 h suggests that PfHRPII exported to the red cells does not undergo bulk endocytic uptake into the parasite throughout trophozoite development, although greater than 80% of the hemoglobin is ingested and digested during this time (Refs. 5Goldberg D.E. Semin. Cell Biol. 1993; 4: 355-361Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar and 28Akompong T. Ghori N. Haldar K. Antimicrob. Agents Chemother. 2000; 44: 88-96Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar and data not shown). However, a small but constant amount of HRPII that corresponds to 3% of total trophozoite protein associates with the pellet fraction throughout asexual parasite growth (Fig. 2 E, ii), suggesting that there are mechanisms to retain a minor portion of PfHRPII in the parasite. Because the total levels of cell associated protein remain constant over time, the data in Fig. 2 argue against significant release of HRPII into the extracellular medium until the infected red blood cell ruptures. An early report (26Howard R.J. Shigehiko U. Aikawa M. Aley S.B. Leech J.H. Lew A.M. Wellems T.E. Rener J. Taylor D.W. J. Cell Biol. 1986; 103: 1269-1277Crossref PubMed Scopus (251) Google Scholar) suggests that a histidine-labeled form of HRPII is exported into the extracellular medium. However definitive evidence obtained by combining short pulse times with appropriate chase times and quantitative immunoprecipitations were not provided. This makes it difficult to evaluate how much of the export detected was due to partial cell lysis. Pulse-chase studies are difficult to undertake with PfHRPII because the protein is methionine-poor and, thus, cannot be metabolically labeled with [35S]methionine with any efficiency. To further examine the relationship between the exported and parasite-associated pools of protein, we expressed intrans-PfHRPII tagged at its C terminus with Myc (see Fig.3 A) under thecam promoter using the pHC1 plasmid to establish the transformed E8 line (see “Materials and Methods”). Our unpublished studies suggested that cam is active at the trophozoite stage (data not shown). Western blots (Fig. 3 B) show that the expression of Myc-tagged HRPII protein in transformed E8 cells is detectable in 18-h rings. Low levels of HRPIImyc are also expressed in 12-h rings and can be detected in single cells by immunofluorescence assays (Fig. 3 A, ii) or by loading 2 × 107 or more of parasite material in Western blots (data not shown). Northern analysis (Fig. 3 C) using a 1-kilobase (kb) probe that detects HRPII RNA shows that transformed cells contain higher levels of message in the trophozoite and schizont stages compared with rings. By the (33–36 h) trophozoite stage, 85% of PfHRPIImyc is released by saponin treatment under conditions where parasite glutamate dehydrogenase and BiP are not released (Fig. 3,D and E). There is some reduction in the fraction released when higher levels of transgene are expressed at later times (>40 h). The reasons for this are unclear. However, because high levels of trans gene expression may be harmful to cells, subsequent analyses of transfected cells was restricted to 33-h trophozoites. A comparison of total HRPII protein in parent 3D7 and transformed E8 lines during intraerythrocytic development undertaken in Fig.4 A (where samples were run on the same gels and processed simultaneously) shows that rings may contain lower levels of the transgene product. However, as the parasites develop into trophozoites (up to 33 h), there is 3–4-fold more total HRPII protein in transformed cells; schizonts (>36 h) contain even higher levels. Transformed trophozoites release 3–4-fold more HRPII protein into the saponin supernatant (Fig.4 B). This closely reflects elevated levels of protein expression in these cells and suggests that, like its endogenous counterpart, PfHRPIImyc is primarily exported out of the parasite into red cell cytoplasm and remains there, even when 80% of the hemoglobin is ingested by the parasite. The release of HRPII and HRPIImyc into saponin-sensitive supernatant fractions suggested that they are soluble proteins in the erythrocytic milieu. However, saponin can intercalate with lipids like cholesterol and may, therefore, affect some forms of protein-membrane association. Thus, to determine what fraction of HRPII in 3D7 and E8 cells are soluble, we subjected cells to hypotonic lysis followed by centrifugation at 100,000 × g. As shown (Fig.4 C), 90 and 80% of HRPII appears to be soluble in the 3D7 and E8 cells, respectively. That 97 and 90% are, respectively, exported argues that the bulk of exported PfHRPII protein in both cell lines is soluble. However, a low fraction 10–20% may have a peripheral association with membranes. In addition, examination of consecutive optical sections through the depth of the infected red cells shows that most of the exported protein is detected in sections at the periphery of the red cell (Fig. 4 D). In contrast in intermediate sections, the signal is not prominent in the red cell. Thus, it is possible that HRPII and HRPIImyc may not freely diffuse through the red cell cytoplasm but may concentrate primarily at the periphery of the red cell and, thus, avoid ingestion along with hemoglobin. As indicated earlier, one previous study has proposed that at the trophozoite stage, HRPII is secreted across the red cell membrane into the extracellular medium (26Howard R.J. Shigehiko U. Aikawa M. Aley S.B. Leech J.H. Lew A.M. Wellems T.E. Rener J. Taylor D.W. J. Cell Biol. 1986; 103: 1269-1277Crossref PubMed Scopus (251) Google Scholar). Our present data (Figs. 2 B and 3 B) suggest that although HRPII protein is not quantitatively released from 3D7 or E8 cells, it localizes to the periphery of the red cells; thus, some fraction of the protein could be on the infected red cell surface. To address this we examined both parent and transformed lines for HRPII associated with the infected cell surface by flow cytometry (Fig.4 E). This is a highly sensitive method for protein determination on single cells as well as in a population. Infected erythrocytes can be distinguished from th

l-Isoaspartyl (d-aspartyl) O-methyltransferase (PCMT1) is a protein repair enzyme that initiates the conversion of abnormald-aspartyl and l-isoaspartyl residues to the normal l-aspartyl form. In the course of this reaction, PCMT1 converts the methyl donor S-adenosylmethionine (AdoMet) to S-adenosylhomocysteine (AdoHcy). Due to the high level of activity of this enzyme, particularly in the brain, it seemed of interest to investigate whether the lack of PCMT1 activity might alter the concentrations of these small molecules. AdoMet and AdoHcy were measured in mice lacking PCMT1 (Pcmt1−/−), as well as in their heterozygous (Pcmt1+/−) and wild type (Pcmt1+/+) littermates. Higher levels of AdoMet and lower levels of AdoHcy were found in the brains of Pcmt1−/−mice, and to a lesser extent in Pcmt1+/− mice, when compared withPcmt1+/+ mice. In addition, these levels appear to be most significantly altered in the hippocampus of the Pcmt1−/−mice. The changes in the AdoMet/AdoHcy ratio could not be attributed to increases in the activities of methionine adenosyltransferase II orS-adenosylhomocysteine hydrolase in the brain tissue of these mice. Because changes in the AdoMet/AdoHcy ratio could potentially alter the overall excitatory state of the brain, this effect may play a role in the progressive epilepsy seen in thePcmt1−/− mice. l-Isoaspartyl (d-aspartyl) O-methyltransferase (PCMT1) is a protein repair enzyme that initiates the conversion of abnormald-aspartyl and l-isoaspartyl residues to the normal l-aspartyl form. In the course of this reaction, PCMT1 converts the methyl donor S-adenosylmethionine (AdoMet) to S-adenosylhomocysteine (AdoHcy). Due to the high level of activity of this enzyme, particularly in the brain, it seemed of interest to investigate whether the lack of PCMT1 activity might alter the concentrations of these small molecules. AdoMet and AdoHcy were measured in mice lacking PCMT1 (Pcmt1−/−), as well as in their heterozygous (Pcmt1+/−) and wild type (Pcmt1+/+) littermates. Higher levels of AdoMet and lower levels of AdoHcy were found in the brains of Pcmt1−/−mice, and to a lesser extent in Pcmt1+/− mice, when compared withPcmt1+/+ mice. In addition, these levels appear to be most significantly altered in the hippocampus of the Pcmt1−/−mice. The changes in the AdoMet/AdoHcy ratio could not be attributed to increases in the activities of methionine adenosyltransferase II orS-adenosylhomocysteine hydrolase in the brain tissue of these mice. Because changes in the AdoMet/AdoHcy ratio could potentially alter the overall excitatory state of the brain, this effect may play a role in the progressive epilepsy seen in thePcmt1−/− mice. l-isoaspartyl (d-aspartyl)O-methyltransferase S-adenosyl-l-methionine S- adenosyl-l-homocysteine 5′-deoxy-5′-(methylthio)adenosine methionine adenosyltransferase II S-adenosyl-l-homocysteine hydrolase 2,2-bis(hydroxymethyl)-2,2′,2“-nitrilotriethanol high performance liquid chromatography One of the most common forms of protein damage in vitroand in vivo is deamidation and isoaspartyl formation caused by deprotonation of the peptide-bond nitrogen and its attack on the side chain carbonyl carbon of l-asparaginyl orl-aspartyl residues (1Linder H. Helliger W. Exp. Gerontol. 2001; 36: 1551-1563Crossref PubMed Scopus (95) Google Scholar, 2Tashima G. Hancock W.S. Canova-Davis E. Aswad D.W. Deamidation and Isoaspartate Formation in Peptides and Proteins. CRC Press, Inc., Boca Raton, FL1995: 167-192Google Scholar). This spontaneous reaction results in the loss of ammonia (from asparaginyl residues) or water (from aspartyl residues) and the formation of the side chain into an intermediate succinimidyl ring. If this ring is hydrolyzed at the α-carbonyl group, the peptide bond is re-routed through the side chain carbonyl resulting in the formation of anl-isoaspartyl residue. The ring is also susceptible to racemization, allowing for the formation of d-aspartyl andd-isoaspartyl residues, as well. These aberrant residues can cause drastic conformational changes in their proteins, resulting in loss of biological activity (1Linder H. Helliger W. Exp. Gerontol. 2001; 36: 1551-1563Crossref PubMed Scopus (95) Google Scholar), increased propensity to aggregate (2Tashima G. Hancock W.S. Canova-Davis E. Aswad D.W. Deamidation and Isoaspartate Formation in Peptides and Proteins. CRC Press, Inc., Boca Raton, FL1995: 167-192Google Scholar), and/or increased immunogenicity (3Mamula M.J. Gee R.J. Elliott J.I. Sette A. Southwood S. Jones P.J. Blier P.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 22321-22327Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (178) Google Scholar). Recent studies have shown that isoaspartyl formation in specific peptides or proteins may be linked to certain disease processes. For example, the presence of isoaspartyl residues in the β-amyloid peptide contributes to its insolubility, and protein isomerization is elevated in β-amyloid peptides and paired helical filaments purified from Alzheimer's disease brains (4Kuo Y.M. Webster S. Emmerling M.R., De Lima N. Roher A.E. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1998; 1406: 291-298Crossref PubMed Scopus (113) Google Scholar, 5Lowenson J.D. Clarke S. Roher A.E. Methods Enzymol. 1999; 309: 89-105Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar, 6Shimizu T. Watanabe A. Ogawara M. Mori H. Shirasawa T. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 2000; 381: 225-234Crossref PubMed Scopus (165) Google Scholar). However, just as cells have mechanisms to combat other forms of damage, they have at least one to restrict the accumulation of isoaspartyl residues. This mechanism involves the enzyme l-isoaspartyl (d-aspartyl)O-methyltransferase (PCMT1).1PCMT1 functions by transferring a methyl group from the moleculeS-adenosylmethionine (AdoMet) to either the α-carboxyl group of the l-isoaspartyl residue or the β-carboxyl group of the d-aspartyl residue (7Murray E.D., Jr. Clarke S. J. Biol. Chem. 1984; 259: 10722-10732Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 8McFadden P.N. Clarke S. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 11503-11511Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 9Griffith S.C. Sawaya M.R. Boutz D.R. Thapar N. Katz J.E. Clarke S. Yeates T.O. J. Mol. Biol. 2001; 313: 1103-1116Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar). The resulting methyl ester is then susceptible to spontaneous hydrolysis leading to the loss of methanol and the re-formation of the succinimidyl ring. If the intermediate ring structure then hydrolyzes at the β-carbonyl, which typically occurs about 30% of the time at physiological pH, the residue returns to the normal l-aspartyl form (10Johnson B.A. Aswad D.W. Biochemistry. 1985; 24: 2581-2586Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar, 11Geiger T. Clarke S. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 785-794Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). However, 70% of the time, the cyclic imide returns to one of the aberrant forms, which can be re-methylated by PCMT1 until the peptide or protein in which it resides is no longer a substrate for the enzyme. Therefore, one side effect of this repair mechanism may be a potentially large consumption of the methyl donor, AdoMet.When AdoMet donates its methyl group it becomesS-adenosylhomocysteine (AdoHcy). The concentration of AdoMet compared with that of AdoHcy is often used as an index for the activity of the AdoMet-dependent methyl transfer system in living organisms (12Baudry M. Chast F. Schwartz J.C. J. Neurochem. 1973; 20: 13-21Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar, 13Hoffman D.R. Cornatzer W.E. Duerre J.A. Can. J. Biochem. 1979; 57: 56-65Crossref PubMed Scopus (185) Google Scholar, 14McKeever M. Molloy A. Weir D.G. Young P.B. Kennedy D.G. Kennedy S. Scott J.M. Clin. Sci. (Lond.). 1995; 88: 73-79Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar). For example, if the AdoMet/AdoHcy ratio were lowered, it might indicate greater AdoMet “consumption” through increased methyltransferase activity. In rat studies, the administration of 3-(3,4-dihydroxyphenyl)-l-alanine (l-dopa) results in a significant increase in the activity of catecholamine-O-methyltransferase causing a reduction in the brain concentration of AdoMet, with a concomitant elevation in the level of AdoHcy, thereby lowering the AdoMet/AdoHcy ratio (15Fuller R.W. Hemrick-Luecke S.K. Perry K.W. J. Pharmacol. Exp. Ther. 1982; 223: 84-89PubMed Google Scholar). However, if 3-(3,4-dihydroxyphenyl)-l-alanine continues to be administered, the level of AdoMet returns to normal due to the feedback regulation of methionine adenosyltransferase II (MAT II), the enzyme that produces AdoMet in the brain (16Zhao W.Q. Latinwo L. Liu X.X. Lee E.S. Lamango N. Charlton C.G. Exp. Neurol. 2001; 171: 127-138Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). Another enzyme that is important in maintaining a proper AdoMet/AdoHcy ratio isS-adenosylhomocysteine hydrolase (SAHH). AdoHcy must be kept from accumulating because many methyltransferases have a higher affinity for AdoHcy than AdoMet, making AdoHcy a potent inhibitor of many methylation reactions (17Poulton J.E. Butt V.S. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1976; 172: 135-142Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar, 18Hoffman D.R. Marion D.W. Cornatzer W.E. Duerre J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 34: 1521-1530Crossref PubMed Scopus (222) Google Scholar, 55Clarke S. Banfield K. Carmel R. Jacobsen D.W. Homocysteine in Health and Disease. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK2001: 63-78Google Scholar).Although the levels of AdoMet and AdoHcy are normally well regulated, there are conditions under which the levels of these small molecules can be altered for prolonged periods, and they are often accompanied by severe physiological complications. For example, deficiencies in folic acid or vitamin B12 can cause a considerable decrease in the AdoMet/AdoHcy ratio (21Bottiglieri T. Nutr. Rev. 1996; 54: 382-390Crossref PubMed Scopus (274) Google Scholar). These deficiencies lead to severe neurological disorders, such as demyelination of the spinal cord characterized by vacuolar myelopathic lesions. It has been suggested that the demyelination is caused by the defect in methylation (21Bottiglieri T. Nutr. Rev. 1996; 54: 382-390Crossref PubMed Scopus (274) Google Scholar). This hypothesis is supported by animal studies showing that similar lesions are produced in mice treated with cycloleucine, an inhibitor of methionine adenosyltransferase (21Bottiglieri T. Nutr. Rev. 1996; 54: 382-390Crossref PubMed Scopus (274) Google Scholar). In the case of deficiencies in glycine N-methyltranferase, a liver enzyme that is believed to serve as an alternate pathway for the conversion of AdoMet to AdoHcy, there is a significant increase in plasma AdoMet/AdoHcy ratios (22Mudd S.H. Cerone R. Schiaffino M.C. Fantasia A.R. Minniti G. Caruso U. Lorini R. Watkins D. Matiaszuk N. Rosenblatt D.S. Schwahn B. Rozen R. LeGros L. Kotb M. Capdevila A. Luka Z. Finkelstein J.D. Tangerman A. Stabler S.P. Allen R.H. Wagner C. J. Inherit. Metab. Dis. 2001; 24: 448-464Crossref PubMed Scopus (128) Google Scholar).
